    Keeping Your Python Codebase Tidy: Linters, Type Checkers, and Workspace Harmony

    After fifteen posts about architecture, patterns, and deployment, let's talk about something equally important but often overlooked: keeping your codebase consistently clean as it grows. I've seen brilliant architectures deteriorate not from bad design decisions, but from gradual erosion of code quality standards. A thousand small inconsistencies eventually make a codebase unmaintainable.

    The clean-py repository uses multiple complementary tools to maintain code quality. This isn't the only way‚Äîit's one approach I've found convenient after years of experimentation. Your team might prefer different tools or workflows, and that's perfectly fine. The key is having a system and sticking to it.

    The Multi-Tool Approach: Why One Tool Isn't Enough

    Each code quality tool serves a different purpose. Trying to find one tool that does everything is like looking for a universal remote that also makes coffee‚Äîtheoretically possible, but probably not optimal at either task.

    Here's the toolkit approach used in clean-py:

    • Black: Formats code (opinions included, debates excluded)
    • isort: Organizes imports consistently
    • Ruff: Fast linting and basic error catching
    • Pylint: Deep code analysis and convention enforcement
    • Pyright: Strict type checking
    • Mypy: Alternative type checking with different strengths
    • Bandit: Security vulnerability scanning
    • Vulture: Dead code detection
    • Radon: Complexity analysis

    Each tool catches different issues. Ruff might miss a design smell that Pylint catches. Pyright might find type issues that Mypy misses (and vice versa). The overlap isn't redundancy‚Äîit's defense in depth.

    Pylint: The Thorough Inspector

    Pylint goes beyond syntax checking to enforce coding standards and catch design issues. While Ruff is blazingly fast for basic checks, Pylint takes its time to perform deeper analysis:

    # .pylintrc
[MASTER]
# Specify a score threshold to be exceeded before program exits with error
fail-under=8.0

# Use multiple processes to speed up Pylint
jobs=4

# Pickle collected data for later comparisons
persistent=yes

# Allow loading of arbitrary C extensions
unsafe-load-any-extension=no

[MESSAGES CONTROL]
# Disable messages that conflict with other tools or are too strict
disable=
    C0111,  # missing-docstring (we use interrogate for this)
    C0103,  # invalid-name (too strict for test functions)
    R0903,  # too-few-public-methods (value objects often have few methods)
    R0801,  # duplicate-code (often false positives in tests)
    W0212,  # protected-access (needed for testing private methods)
    E1101,  # no-member (false positives with SQLAlchemy)
    W0511,  # fixme (we track TODOs differently)

[REPORTS]
# Set the output format
output-format=colorized

# Include message's id in output
include-ids=yes

# Include symbolic ids of messages in output
symbol=yes

# Put messages in separate files
files-output=no

# Template for output
msg-template={path}:{line}: [{msg_id}({symbol}), {obj}] {msg}

[BASIC]
# Naming conventions
argument-naming-style=snake_case
attr-naming-style=snake_case
class-attribute-naming-style=any
class-naming-style=PascalCase
const-naming-style=UPPER_CASE
function-naming-style=snake_case
method-naming-style=snake_case
module-naming-style=snake_case
variable-naming-style=snake_case

# Good names which should always be accepted
good-names=i,j,k,ex,Run,_,id,ok,db

# Bad names which should always be refused
bad-names=foo,bar,baz,toto,tutu,tata

[DESIGN]
# Maximum number of arguments for functions
max-args=7

# Maximum number of attributes for a class
max-attributes=10

# Maximum number of boolean expressions in an if statement
max-bool-expr=5

# Maximum number of branch for function/method body
max-branches=12

# Maximum number of locals for function/method body
max-locals=15

# Maximum number of parents for a class
max-parents=7

# Maximum number of public methods for a class
max-public-methods=20

# Maximum number of return/yield for function/method body
max-returns=6

# Maximum number of statements in function/method body
max-statements=50

# Minimum number of public methods for a class
min-public-methods=0

[SIMILARITIES]
# Minimum lines number of a similarity
min-similarity-lines=4

# Ignore comments when computing similarities
ignore-comments=yes

# Ignore docstrings when computing similarities
ignore-docstrings=yes

# Ignore imports when computing similarities
ignore-imports=yes

[TYPECHECK]
# List of class names for which member attributes should not be checked
ignored-classes=optparse.Values,thread._local,_thread._local,SQLAlchemy,scoped_session

# List of module names for which member attributes should not be checked
ignored-modules=alembic.context,sqlalchemy.orm

[IMPORTS]
# Allow wildcard imports from modules
allow-wildcard-with-all=no

# Analyse import fallback blocks
analyse-fallback-blocks=no

# Deprecated modules which should not be used
deprecated-modules=optparse,tkinter.tix

[EXCEPTIONS]
# Exceptions that will emit a warning when being caught
overgeneral-exceptions=BaseException,Exception

    Pylint catches issues other tools miss:

    # Pylint catches these design issues

class OrderService:
    def process_order(self, order_id, customer_id, product_ids, 
                      quantities, prices, discounts, shipping_address,
                      billing_address, payment_method):  # too-many-arguments
        """Process an order with too many parameters."""
        pass

def calculate_total(items):
    # too-many-branches, too-many-statements
    total = 0
    for item in items:
        if item.type == 'product':
            if item.taxable:
                if item.category == 'food':
                    total += item.price * 1.05
                elif item.category == 'clothing':
                    total += item.price * 1.08
                else:
                    total += item.price * 1.10
            else:
                total += item.price
        elif item.type == 'service':
            if item.duration > 4:
                total += item.price * 1.5
            else:
                total += item.price
    # ... 20 more conditions
    return total

# Pylint suggests refactoring to:
class PriceCalculator:
    def calculate_total(self, items):
        return sum(self._calculate_item_price(item) for item in items)

    def _calculate_item_price(self, item):
        if item.type == 'product':
            return self._calculate_product_price(item)
        elif item.type == 'service':
            return self._calculate_service_price(item)
        return item.price

    Pyright: The Strict Type Guardian

    While Mypy is popular, Pyright (which powers Pylance in VS Code) offers some advantages, especially for large codebases:

    // pyrightconfig.json
{

  "reportUnknownParameterType": "warning",
  "reportUnknownArgumentType": "warning",

  "reportUnknownVariableType": "warning",
  "reportUnknownMemberType": "warning",
  "reportUnnecessaryIsInstance": "warning",
  "reportUnnecessaryCast": "error",

  "reportUnnecessaryTypeIgnoreComment": "warning"
}

    Pyright's advantages include: - Faster performance on large codebases - Better IDE integration (especially VS Code) - More accurate type inference in some cases - Better support for type narrowing

    Example where Pyright shines:

    from typing import Union, Literal

def process_value(value: Union[int, str]) -> str:
    # Pyright understands type narrowing better
    if isinstance(value, int):
        # Pyright knows value is int here
        return str(value + 10)
    else:
        # Pyright knows value is str here
        return value.upper()

# Pyright handles Literal types well
Status = Literal["pending", "approved", "rejected"]

def handle_status(status: Status) -> None:
    # Pyright ensures exhaustive handling
    match status:
        case "pending":
            print("Waiting")
        case "approved":
            print("Good to go")
        # Pyright warns: Case "rejected" not handled

    Workspace Configuration: Team Consistency

    One of the most underrated features for team development is workspace configuration. This ensures everyone has the same setup:

    // .vscode/settings.json
{
  "python.defaultInterpreterPath": "${workspaceFolder}/.venv/bin/python",
  "python.linting.enabled": true,
  "python.linting.pylintEnabled": true,
  "python.linting.pylintPath": "${workspaceFolder}/.venv/bin/pylint",
  "python.linting.mypyEnabled": true,
  "python.linting.mypyPath": "${workspaceFolder}/.venv/bin/mypy",

  "python.linting.banditPath": "${workspaceFolder}/.venv/bin/bandit",
  "python.formatting.provider": "black",
  "python.formatting.blackPath": "${workspaceFolder}/.venv/bin/black",
  "python.sortImports.path": "${workspaceFolder}/.venv/bin/isort",
  "python.testing.pytestEnabled": true,
  "python.testing.pytestPath": "${workspaceFolder}/.venv/bin/pytest",
  "python.testing.unittestEnabled": false,
  "python.testing.autoTestDiscoverOnSaveEnabled": true,
  "python.languageServer": "Pylance",
  "python.analysis.typeCheckingMode": "strict",
  "python.analysis.autoImportCompletions": true,
  "python.analysis.autoSearchPaths": true,
  "python.analysis.diagnosticMode": "workspace",
  "python.analysis.stubPath": "typings",
  "python.analysis.extraPaths": ["src"],
  "python.analysis.reportMissingImports": "error",
  "python.analysis.reportMissingTypeStubs": "warning",
  "python.analysis.reportUnusedImport": "warning",

    EditorConfig: Universal Editor Settings

    For teams using different editors, EditorConfig provides consistency:

    # .editorconfig
root = true

[*]
charset = utf-8
end_of_line = lf
insert_final_newline = true
trim_trailing_whitespace = true
indent_style = space

[*.py]
indent_size = 4
max_line_length = 88

[*.{json,yaml,yml,toml}]
indent_size = 2

[*.md]
trim_trailing_whitespace = false

[Makefile]
indent_style = tab

[*.{js,jsx,ts,tsx}]
indent_size = 2

[*.sql]
indent_size = 2

    Make Commands: One Interface to Rule Them All

    The Makefile provides a consistent interface regardless of the underlying tools:

    # Additional Make commands for code maintenance

.PHONY: lint-all
lint-all: ## Run all linting tools
    @echo "Running comprehensive linting..."
    @echo "1/5 Ruff..."
    @ruff check src tests
    @echo "2/5 Pylint..."
    @pylint src --rcfile=.pylintrc
    @echo "3/5 Mypy..."
    @mypy src --strict
    @echo "4/5 Pyright..."
    @pyright src
    @echo "5/5 Bandit..."
    @bandit -r src -ll
    @echo "‚úÖ All linting passed!"

.PHONY: fix-all
fix-all: ## Auto-fix all possible issues
    @echo "Auto-fixing code issues..."
    @black src tests
    @isort src tests
    @ruff check --fix src tests
    @autoflake --in-place --remove-all-unused-imports --recursive src tests
    @echo "‚úÖ Auto-fixes applied!"

.PHONY: complexity
complexity: ## Analyze code complexity
    @echo "Analyzing code complexity..."
    @radon cc src --min B --show-complexity --total-average
    @radon mi src --min B --show
    @echo ""
    @echo "Cyclomatic Complexity:"
    @echo "  A: 1-5   (low risk - simple block)"
    @echo "  B: 6-10  (low risk - well structured)"
    @echo "  C: 11-20 (moderate risk - more complex)"
    @echo "  D: 21-50 (high risk - complex, alarming)"
    @echo "  E: >50   (very high risk - untestable)"

.PHONY: dead-code
dead-code: ## Find dead code
    @echo "Searching for dead code..."
    @vulture src --min-confidence 80

.PHONY: todos
todos: ## List all TODOs and FIXMEs
    @echo "TODOs and FIXMEs:"
    @grep -r "TODO\|FIXME\|HACK\|XXX" src tests --exclude-dir=__pycache__ || echo "No TODOs found!"

.PHONY: deps-check
deps-check: ## Check dependency health
    @echo "Checking dependencies..."
    @pip list --outdated
    @echo ""
    @echo "Security check:"
    @safety check || true
    @echo ""
    @echo "License check:"
    @pip-licenses --with-urls --format=markdown

.PHONY: stats
stats: ## Show codebase statistics
    @echo "Codebase Statistics:"
    @echo "==================="
    @echo "Lines of Code:"
    @cloc src --exclude-dir=__pycache__
    @echo ""
    @echo "File Count:"
    @find src -name "*.py" | wc -l
    @echo ""
    @echo "Test Coverage:"
    @coverage report --skip-covered --sort=cover

.PHONY: health
health: ## Full codebase health check
    @echo "üè• Running full health check..."
    @$(MAKE) lint-all
    @$(MAKE) test
    @$(MAKE) complexity
    @$(MAKE) dead-code
    @$(MAKE) deps-check
    @echo "‚úÖ Codebase is healthy!"

.PHONY: pre-commit-all
pre-commit-all: ## Run pre-commit on all files
    @pre-commit run --all-files

.PHONY: clean-deep
clean-deep: clean ## Deep clean including caches and environments
    @echo "Deep cleaning..."
    @rm -rf .venv venv
    @rm -rf node_modules
    @rm -rf .tox
    @rm -rf .eggs *.egg-info
    @find . -type d -name ".pytest_cache" -exec rm -rf {} + 2>/dev/null || true
    @find . -type d -name ".mypy_cache" -exec rm -rf {} + 2>/dev/null || true
    @find . -type d -name ".ruff_cache" -exec rm -rf {} + 2>/dev/null || true
    @find . -type d -name "__pycache__" -exec rm -rf {} + 2>/dev/null || true
    @echo "‚úÖ Deep clean complete!"

    Alternative Approaches

    This multi-tool approach works well for the clean-py project, but it's not the only way. Here are alternatives worth considering:

    The Minimalist Approach

    Some teams prefer fewer tools: - Ruff only: Fast and covers most linting needs - Black + Ruff: Formatting plus linting - Poetry + Black + Pytest: Simplified toolchain

    The All-in-One Approach

    Tools that try to do everything: - Prospector: Wraps multiple tools - Sourcery: AI-powered code review - SonarQube: Enterprise code quality platform

    The Progressive Approach

    Start simple, add tools as needed: 1. Start with Black (formatting) 2. Add Ruff (fast linting) 3. Add Mypy (type checking) 4. Add Pylint (deep analysis) when needed 5. Add specialized tools (security, complexity) for mature projects

    Continuous Code Health Monitoring

    Beyond running tools, monitor code health trends:

    # scripts/code_health.py
import json
import subprocess
from datetime import datetime
from pathlib import Path

def collect_metrics():
    """Collect code health metrics."""
    metrics = {
        "timestamp": datetime.now().isoformat(),
        "metrics": {}
    }

    # Complexity metrics
    result = subprocess.run(
        ["radon", "cc", "src", "--json"],
        capture_output=True,
        text=True
    )
    complexity_data = json.loads(result.stdout)

    total_complexity = 0
    high_complexity_functions = 0

    for file_data in complexity_data.values():
        for func in file_data:
            if isinstance(func, dict):
                total_complexity += func.get("complexity", 0)
                if func.get("complexity", 0) > 10:
                    high_complexity_functions += 1

    metrics["metrics"]["average_complexity"] = total_complexity / max(len(complexity_data), 1)
    metrics["metrics"]["high_complexity_functions"] = high_complexity_functions

    # Pylint score
    result = subprocess.run(
        ["pylint", "src", "--output-format=json"],
        capture_output=True,
        text=True
    )
    if result.stdout:
        pylint_data = json.loads(result.stdout)
        metrics["metrics"]["pylint_score"] = pylint_data.get("score", 0)

    # Type coverage (pyright)
    result = subprocess.run(
        ["pyright", "--outputjson"],
        capture_output=True,
        text=True
    )
    if result.stdout:
        pyright_data = json.loads(result.stdout)
        metrics["metrics"]["type_errors"] = pyright_data["summary"]["errorCount"]
        metrics["metrics"]["type_warnings"] = pyright_data["summary"]["warningCount"]

    return metrics

def generate_report(metrics):
    """Generate health report."""
    print("üìä Code Health Report")
    print("=" * 50)
    print(f"Timestamp: {metrics['timestamp']}")
    print(f"Average Complexity: {metrics['metrics'].get('average_complexity', 0):.2f}")
    print(f"High Complexity Functions: {metrics['metrics'].get('high_complexity_functions', 0)}")
    print(f"Pylint Score: {metrics['metrics'].get('pylint_score', 0):.2f}/10")
    print(f"Type Errors: {metrics['metrics'].get('type_errors', 0)}")
    print(f"Type Warnings: {metrics['metrics'].get('type_warnings', 0)}")

    # Save to file for tracking
    history_file = Path("code_health_history.json")
    history = []
    if history_file.exists():
        history = json.loads(history_file.read_text())
    history.append(metrics)
    history_file.write_text(json.dumps(history, indent=2))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    metrics = collect_metrics()
    generate_report(metrics)

    Common Pitfalls and Solutions

    Tool Overload

    Problem: Too many tools slow down development. Solution: Start with essentials, add tools when problems arise.

    Configuration Drift

    Problem: Local configs diverge from team standards. Solution: Version control all configuration files, use workspace settings.

    Ignored Warnings

    Problem: Teams ignore tool output due to noise. Solution: Configure tools properly, fix warnings immediately or suppress with reason.

    Performance Issues

    Problem: Linting takes too long. Solution: Use faster tools (Ruff), run expensive checks only in CI.

    The Human Element

    Tools don't maintain code quality‚Äîpeople do. The best tooling setup fails if the team doesn't buy in. Here's what works:

    1. Explain the Why: Show how tools save time and prevent bugs
    2. Start Gradually: Don't enable all checks at once
    3. Fix Together: Make fixing warnings a team activity
    4. Celebrate Improvements: Share metrics showing quality improvements
    5. Allow Flexibility: Some rules might not fit your project

    Conclusion

    Keeping a Python codebase tidy isn't about following a prescriptive set of rules‚Äîit's about finding what works for your team and automating it. The clean-py repository demonstrates one approach using multiple complementary tools, comprehensive configuration, and convenient Make commands.

    The specific tools matter less than having a system. Whether you use Pylint or only Ruff, Pyright or Mypy, VS Code or PyCharm‚Äîwhat matters is consistency, automation, and team buy-in. Start with the basics, add tools as needed, and always prioritize developer experience alongside code quality.

    Remember: Clean code isn't an end goal‚Äîit's a means to deliver value efficiently. The best codebase is one that's clean enough to maintain, flexible enough to evolve, and simple enough for your team to understand.

    The tools and configurations shown here are one way of achieving this. Your way might be different, and that's perfectly fine. The important thing is to have a way, document it, automate it, and stick to it.

    Evolving Your Architecture: Patterns for Growth

    Software architecture isn't a one-time design decision‚Äîit's a living system that must evolve as your business grows, requirements change, and technology advances. The greatest architectural challenge isn't building the perfect system from day one; it's creating a foundation that can adapt and scale while maintaining code quality, team productivity, and system reliability.

    The clean-py repository demonstrates evolution-friendly patterns that have guided real-world applications from startup MVPs to enterprise-scale systems processing millions of requests daily. This isn't theoretical advice‚Äîit's battle-tested strategies for architectural evolution that preserve your investment while enabling growth.

    The Evolution Imperative

    I've watched too many promising startups hit the "architectural wall"‚Äîthe moment when their initial system design becomes the limiting factor in their growth. The symptoms are always the same:

    • New features take exponentially longer to implement
    • Simple changes require modifications across multiple systems
    • The development team spends more time fighting the architecture than building features
    • Scaling requires complete rewrites instead of incremental improvements
    • Technical debt compounds faster than business value creation

    A recent client experienced this perfectly. Their e-commerce platform started as a Flask monolith serving 100 orders per day. Eighteen months later, they were processing 10,000 orders daily, had grown from 3 to 25 engineers, and needed to support multiple sales channels. Their architecture had become their biggest constraint.

    The solution wasn't a big bang rewrite‚Äîit was systematic evolution using Clean Architecture principles as the foundation for incremental transformation.

    The Clean-Py Tool Arsenal: Foundation for Evolution

    Before diving into evolution principles, let's examine how the clean-py repository uses specific tools to maintain architectural cleanliness and enable smooth evolution. These tools aren't just development conveniences‚Äîthey're the foundation that makes architectural evolution possible without code rot.

    Strategic Tool Selection in Clean-Py

    The repository demonstrates a carefully curated tool selection where each tool serves a specific purpose in maintaining architectural integrity:

    How Tools Enable Clean Architecture

    1. Type Safety with Mypy and Pydantic

    Clean-py leverages Python's type system to enforce architectural boundaries at the type level:

    # src/domain/repositories/order_repository.py
from abc import ABC, abstractmethod
from typing import Optional, List
from ..entities.order import Order
from ..value_objects.order_id import OrderId

class OrderRepository(ABC):
    """Repository interface - domain layer defines the contract"""

    @abstractmethod
    async def save(self, order: Order) -> Order:
        """Type hints enforce correct entity usage"""
        pass

    @abstractmethod
    async def get_by_id(self, order_id: OrderId) -> Optional[Order]:
        """Value objects like OrderId prevent primitive obsession"""
        pass

# src/infrastructure/repositories/postgres_order_repository.py
from typing import Optional
from sqlalchemy.ext.asyncio import AsyncSession
from ...domain.repositories.order_repository import OrderRepository
from ...domain.entities.order import Order
from ...domain.value_objects.order_id import OrderId

class PostgresOrderRepository(OrderRepository):
    """Infrastructure implementation - must satisfy domain interface"""

    def __init__(self, session: AsyncSession):
        self.session = session

    async def save(self, order: Order) -> Order:
        # Mypy ensures this returns Order, not OrderModel
        order_model = self._to_model(order)
        self.session.add(order_model)
        await self.session.commit()
        return order  # Type safety enforced

    async def get_by_id(self, order_id: OrderId) -> Optional[Order]:
        # OrderId value object prevents passing raw strings
        result = await self.session.get(OrderModel, str(order_id))
        return self._to_entity(result) if result else None

    Mypy catches architectural violations at development time: - Domain depending on infrastructure (import error) - Wrong types crossing boundaries (type error) - Missing interface implementations (abstract method error)

    2. Code Organization with Ruff and isort

    Ruff's comprehensive rule set maintains consistent code organization that reflects architectural boundaries:

    3. Consistent Formatting with Black

    Black eliminates formatting debates, ensuring the codebase remains readable as it evolves:

    # Before Black - inconsistent formatting obscures architecture
def process_order(order_id,customer_id,items,
                 shipping_address,billing_address,
    payment_method):
    if not items: return None
    total=sum([item.price*item.quantity for item in items])
    order=Order(order_id,customer_id,total)
    return order

# After Black - clean, consistent, architectural intent is clear
def process_order(
    order_id: OrderId,
    customer_id: CustomerId,
    items: List[OrderItem],
    shipping_address: Address,
    billing_address: Address,
    payment_method: PaymentMethod,
) -> Optional[Order]:
    if not items:
        return None

    total = sum(item.price * item.quantity for item in items)
    order = Order(order_id, customer_id, total)
    return order
    4. Testing Infrastructure with Pytest

    Clean-py's test structure mirrors the architecture, making it easy to test each layer independently:

    # tests/unit/domain/test_order.py
import pytest
from src.domain.entities.order import Order
from src.domain.value_objects.money import Money

class TestOrder:
    """Domain tests - no infrastructure dependencies"""

    def test_order_total_calculation(self):
        # Pure domain logic testing
        order = Order.create(customer_id="123")
        order.add_item(product_id="ABC", quantity=2, price=Money(10.00))

        assert order.total == Money(20.00)

    def test_order_business_rules(self):
        order = Order.create(customer_id="123")

        with pytest.raises(DomainException):
            order.confirm()  # Can't confirm empty order

# tests/integration/repositories/test_order_repository.py
class TestOrderRepository:
    """Integration tests - test infrastructure with real dependencies"""

    @pytest.mark.asyncio
    async def test_save_and_retrieve(self, db_session):
        repo = PostgresOrderRepository(db_session)
        order = Order.create(customer_id="123")

        saved = await repo.save(order)
        retrieved = await repo.get_by_id(saved.id)

        assert retrieved == saved

    Architecture Validation Scripts

    Clean-py includes custom scripts that enforce architectural rules:

    # scripts/check_architecture.py
import ast
import os
from pathlib import Path
from typing import List, Set

class ArchitectureChecker(ast.NodeVisitor):
    """Validates Clean Architecture dependency rules"""

    def __init__(self):
        self.violations = []
        self.current_file = None
        self.current_layer = None

    def check_project(self, src_path: Path) -> List[str]:
        """Check entire project for architectural violations"""
        for py_file in src_path.rglob("*.py"):
            self.check_file(py_file)
        return self.violations

    def check_file(self, file_path: Path):
        """Check single file for violations"""
        self.current_file = file_path
        self.current_layer = self._determine_layer(file_path)

        with open(file_path) as f:
            tree = ast.parse(f.read())
            self.visit(tree)

    def visit_Import(self, node):
        """Check import statements for violations"""
        for alias in node.names:
            self._check_import(alias.name)

    def visit_ImportFrom(self, node):
        """Check from-import statements for violations"""
        if node.module:
            self._check_import(node.module)

    def _determine_layer(self, file_path: Path) -> str:
        """Determine architectural layer from file path"""
        parts = file_path.parts
        if "domain" in parts:
            return "domain"
        elif "application" in parts:
            return "application"
        elif "infrastructure" in parts:
            return "infrastructure"
        elif "presentation" in parts:
            return "presentation"
        return "unknown"

    def _check_import(self, module: str):
        """Check if import violates architectural rules"""
        if not module.startswith("src"):
            return  # External import, allowed

        imported_layer = self._get_layer_from_module(module)

        # Check dependency rules
        if self.current_layer == "domain":
            if imported_layer in ["application", "infrastructure", "presentation"]:
                self.violations.append(
                    f"{self.current_file}: Domain layer importing from {imported_layer}"
                )

        elif self.current_layer == "application":
            if imported_layer in ["infrastructure", "presentation"]:
                self.violations.append(
                    f"{self.current_file}: Application layer importing from {imported_layer}"
                )

        elif self.current_layer == "infrastructure":
            if imported_layer == "presentation":
                self.violations.append(
                    f"{self.current_file}: Infrastructure layer importing from presentation"
                )

# Run in CI/CD
if __name__ == "__main__":
    checker = ArchitectureChecker()
    violations = checker.check_project(Path("src"))

    if violations:
        print("‚ùå Architecture violations found:")
        for v in violations:
            print(f"  - {v}")
        exit(1)
    else:
        print("‚úÖ No architecture violations found")

    How These Tools Enable Evolution

    The combination of these tools creates a safety net that makes architectural evolution possible:

    1. Refactoring Confidence: Comprehensive type checking and tests mean you can refactor fearlessly
    2. Consistent Codebase: Formatting and linting tools ensure the codebase remains readable as it grows
    3. Architectural Integrity: Custom validation scripts prevent architectural drift
    4. Quick Feedback: Pre-commit hooks catch issues before they enter the repository
    5. Team Alignment: Shared tooling ensures everyone follows the same standards
    # .pre-commit-config.yaml - Automated quality gates
repos:

    hooks:

  - repo: https://github.com/charliermarsh/ruff-pre-commit

        entry: radon cc src --min C --no-assert
        language: system
        pass_filenames: false

    This tool infrastructure isn't overhead‚Äîit's what makes the clean-py architecture sustainable and evolvable. Each tool serves a specific purpose in maintaining the integrity of the Clean Architecture while enabling the flexibility needed for evolution.

    Evolution Principles

    With this tool foundation in place, successful architectural evolution follows consistent patterns:

    1. Preserve Business Logic Investment

    Your domain logic‚Äîthe core business rules that differentiate your product‚Äîshould remain stable even as infrastructure evolves. Clean Architecture's dependency inversion principle ensures business logic never depends on technical implementation details.

    # Domain layer remains unchanged during evolution
class OrderService:
    def __init__(self, order_repository: OrderRepository):
        self.order_repository = order_repository

    async def create_order(self, order_data: CreateOrderCommand) -> Order:
        # Business logic never changes
        order = Order.create(
            customer_id=order_data.customer_id,
            items=order_data.items,
            shipping_address=order_data.shipping_address
        )

        # Validate business rules
        self._validate_order_rules(order)

        # Save through repository interface (implementation can evolve)
        return await self.order_repository.save(order)

# Infrastructure evolves while business logic remains stable
# Evolution 1: In-memory repository for testing
class InMemoryOrderRepository(OrderRepository):
    def __init__(self):
        self._orders = {}

    async def save(self, order: Order) -> Order:
        self._orders[order.id] = order
        return order

# Evolution 2: SQL database for production
class SQLOrderRepository(OrderRepository):
    def __init__(self, db_session):
        self.db_session = db_session

    async def save(self, order: Order) -> Order:
        # SQL implementation
        pass

# Evolution 3: Event-sourced repository for audit requirements
class EventSourcedOrderRepository(OrderRepository):
    def __init__(self, event_store):
        self.event_store = event_store

    async def save(self, order: Order) -> Order:
        # Event sourcing implementation
        events = order.get_uncommitted_events()
        await self.event_store.append_events(order.id, events)
        return order

    2. Enable Incremental Migration

    Rather than big-bang rewrites, successful evolution happens incrementally. The Strangler Fig pattern allows you to gradually replace system components while maintaining system functionality.

    # Legacy system integration during transition
class LegacyOrderService:
    """Legacy order service being gradually replaced"""

    def create_order(self, order_data: dict) -> dict:
        # Legacy implementation
        pass

class ModernOrderService:
    """New Clean Architecture implementation"""

    def __init__(self, order_use_case: CreateOrderUseCase):
        self.order_use_case = order_use_case

    async def create_order(self, order_data: CreateOrderCommand) -> Order:
        return await self.order_use_case.execute(order_data)

class OrderServiceRouter:
    """Routes requests between legacy and modern implementations"""

    def __init__(
        self, 
        legacy_service: LegacyOrderService,
        modern_service: ModernOrderService,
        feature_flags: FeatureFlags
    ):
        self.legacy_service = legacy_service
        self.modern_service = modern_service
        self.feature_flags = feature_flags

    async def create_order(self, order_data: dict) -> dict:
        # Gradual migration based on feature flags
        customer_id = order_data.get('customer_id')

        if await self.feature_flags.is_enabled('modern_order_service', customer_id):
            # Use modern implementation
            command = self._convert_to_command(order_data)
            order = await self.modern_service.create_order(command)
            return self._convert_to_legacy_format(order)
        else:
            # Fall back to legacy implementation
            return self.legacy_service.create_order(order_data)

    def _convert_to_command(self, order_data: dict) -> CreateOrderCommand:
        """Convert legacy format to modern command"""
        return CreateOrderCommand(
            customer_id=order_data['customer_id'],
            items=[OrderItem(**item) for item in order_data['items']],
            shipping_address=Address(**order_data['shipping_address'])
        )

    def _convert_to_legacy_format(self, order: Order) -> dict:
        """Convert modern order to legacy format"""
        return {
            'order_id': str(order.id),
            'status': order.status.value,
            'total': float(order.total_amount.amount)
        }

    3. Anticipate Scale Requirements

    Design interfaces and abstractions that can handle future scale requirements without requiring complete rewrites.

    # Repository interface designed for scale evolution
from abc import ABC, abstractmethod
from typing import List, Optional, Protocol

class ScalableOrderRepository(ABC):
    """Repository interface designed to evolve with scale requirements"""

    @abstractmethod
    async def save(self, order: Order) -> Order:
        """Save single order"""
        pass

    @abstractmethod
    async def save_batch(self, orders: List[Order]) -> List[Order]:
        """Batch save for high-throughput scenarios"""
        pass

    @abstractmethod
    async def get_by_id(self, order_id: str) -> Optional[Order]:
        """Get single order"""
        pass

    @abstractmethod
    async def get_by_customer_id(
        self, 
        customer_id: str, 
        limit: int = 50,
        offset: int = 0
    ) -> List[Order]:
        """Paginated customer orders"""
        pass

    @abstractmethod
    async def search(self, criteria: OrderSearchCriteria) -> OrderSearchResult:
        """Flexible search interface for complex queries"""
        pass

# Evolution from simple to sophisticated implementations
class SimpleOrderRepository(ScalableOrderRepository):
    """Initial implementation for low scale"""

    async def save_batch(self, orders: List[Order]) -> List[Order]:
        # Simple loop for initial implementation
        results = []
        for order in orders:
            result = await self.save(order)
            results.append(result)
        return results

class HighPerformanceOrderRepository(ScalableOrderRepository):
    """Evolved implementation for high scale"""

    async def save_batch(self, orders: List[Order]) -> List[Order]:
        # Optimized batch operations
        async with self.db.transaction():
            return await self.db.bulk_insert(orders)

    async def search(self, criteria: OrderSearchCriteria) -> OrderSearchResult:
        # Sophisticated search with caching and indexing
        cache_key = criteria.cache_key()

        if cached_result := await self.cache.get(cache_key):
            return cached_result

        result = await self._execute_search(criteria)
        await self.cache.set(cache_key, result, ttl=300)
        return result

    Evolutionary Patterns

    Pattern 1: Modular Monolith to Microservices

    Start with a well-structured monolith and evolve to microservices based on actual scaling needs, not theoretical benefits.

    # Phase 1: Modular Monolith with Clear Boundaries
class ECommerceApplication:
    """Modular monolith with clear service boundaries"""

    def __init__(self):
        # Each module is independently deployable logic
        self.order_service = OrderService()
        self.inventory_service = InventoryService()
        self.payment_service = PaymentService()
        self.notification_service = NotificationService()

    async def process_order(self, order_request: CreateOrderRequest):
        # Cross-module coordination within single process
        order = await self.order_service.create_order(order_request)
        await self.inventory_service.reserve_items(order.items)
        await self.payment_service.process_payment(order.payment_info)
        await self.notification_service.send_confirmation(order)
        return order

# Phase 2: Extract High-Value Services
class DistributedOrderProcessor:
    """Hybrid approach: some services extracted, others remain monolithic"""

    def __init__(
        self,
        order_service: OrderService,  # Still in monolith
        inventory_service: InventoryService,  # Still in monolith
        payment_service: PaymentServiceClient,  # Extracted microservice
        notification_service: NotificationServiceClient  # Extracted microservice
    ):
        self.order_service = order_service
        self.inventory_service = inventory_service
        self.payment_service = payment_service
        self.notification_service = notification_service

    async def process_order(self, order_request: CreateOrderRequest):
        # Mixed local and remote calls
        order = await self.order_service.create_order(order_request)
        await self.inventory_service.reserve_items(order.items)

        # Remote service calls
        payment_result = await self.payment_service.process_payment({
            'amount': order.total_amount,
            'payment_method': order.payment_method_id
        })

        await self.notification_service.send_confirmation({
            'order_id': str(order.id),
            'customer_email': order.customer_email
        })

        return order

# Phase 3: Full Microservices with Orchestration
class MicroservicesOrderProcessor:
    """Full microservices architecture with proper orchestration"""

    def __init__(self, saga_orchestrator: SagaOrchestrator):
        self.saga_orchestrator = saga_orchestrator

    async def process_order(self, order_request: CreateOrderRequest):
        # Use saga pattern for distributed transaction management
        saga = OrderProcessingSaga()
        return await self.saga_orchestrator.execute(saga, order_request)

class OrderProcessingSaga:
    """Saga pattern for distributed order processing"""

    def __init__(self):
        self.steps = [
            SagaStep('create_order', 'cancel_order'),
            SagaStep('reserve_inventory', 'release_inventory'),
            SagaStep('process_payment', 'refund_payment'),
            SagaStep('send_confirmation', 'send_cancellation')
        ]

    async def execute(self, context: SagaContext) -> OrderResult:
        completed_steps = []

        try:
            for step in self.steps:
                result = await step.execute(context)
                completed_steps.append((step, result))
                context.add_result(step.name, result)

            return OrderResult.success(context.order)

        except Exception as e:
            # Compensate completed steps in reverse order
            for step, result in reversed(completed_steps):
                await step.compensate(context, result)

            return OrderResult.failure(str(e))

    Pattern 2: Data Architecture Evolution

    Data architecture often needs the most careful evolution, as data migration is risky and expensive.

    # Evolution 1: Single Database with Domain Tables
class SingleDatabaseRepository:
    """Traditional approach with domain-specific tables"""

    def __init__(self, db_session):
        self.db = db_session

    async def save_order(self, order: Order):
        # Direct table mapping
        order_record = OrderRecord(
            id=order.id,
            customer_id=order.customer_id,
            status=order.status.value,
            total_amount=order.total_amount.amount
        )
        await self.db.save(order_record)

        for item in order.items:
            item_record = OrderItemRecord(
                order_id=order.id,
                product_id=item.product_id,
                quantity=item.quantity,
                unit_price=item.unit_price.amount
            )
            await self.db.save(item_record)

# Evolution 2: Read/Write Separation (CQRS)
class CQRSOrderRepository:
    """Separate read and write models for better performance"""

    def __init__(self, write_db, read_db, event_bus):
        self.write_db = write_db
        self.read_db = read_db
        self.event_bus = event_bus

    async def save_order(self, order: Order):
        # Write to normalized tables
        async with self.write_db.transaction():
            await self._save_order_aggregate(order)

        # Publish event for read model update
        await self.event_bus.publish(
            OrderCreatedEvent(order_id=order.id, order_data=order.to_dict())
        )

    async def get_order_summary(self, order_id: str) -> OrderSummary:
        # Read from denormalized view
        return await self.read_db.get_order_summary(order_id)

# Evolution 3: Event Sourcing for Complete Auditability
class EventSourcedOrderRepository:
    """Full event sourcing for complex business requirements"""

    def __init__(self, event_store, snapshot_store):
        self.event_store = event_store
        self.snapshot_store = snapshot_store

    async def save_order(self, order: Order):
        # Save domain events
        events = order.get_uncommitted_events()
        await self.event_store.append_events(
            stream_id=str(order.id),
            events=events,
            expected_version=order.version
        )

        # Update snapshot if needed
        if len(events) > 10:  # Snapshot every 10 events
            await self.snapshot_store.save_snapshot(order)

        order.mark_events_as_committed()

    async def get_order(self, order_id: str) -> Optional[Order]:
        # Try to load from snapshot first
        snapshot = await self.snapshot_store.get_snapshot(order_id)

        if snapshot:
            order = snapshot.order
            from_version = snapshot.version + 1
        else:
            order = None
            from_version = 0

        # Apply events since snapshot
        events = await self.event_store.get_events(order_id, from_version)

        if not order and events:
            order = Order.from_events(events)
        elif order and events:
            order.apply_events(events)

        return order

    Pattern 3: API Evolution Strategies

    APIs must evolve without breaking existing clients, requiring careful versioning and backward compatibility strategies.

    # API Versioning Strategy
from enum import Enum
from typing import Union, Any, Dict
from pydantic import BaseModel, Field

class APIVersion(Enum):
    V1 = "1.0"
    V2 = "2.0"
    V3 = "3.0"

# Version 1: Original API
class OrderResponseV1(BaseModel):
    id: str
    status: str
    total: float
    items: List[Dict[str, Any]]

# Version 2: Enhanced with additional fields (backward compatible)
class OrderResponseV2(BaseModel):
    id: str
    status: str
    total: float
    currency: str = Field(default="USD")  # New field with default
    items: List[Dict[str, Any]]
    shipping_address: Optional[Dict[str, Any]] = None  # New optional field

    @classmethod
    def from_v1(cls, v1_response: OrderResponseV1) -> 'OrderResponseV2':
        """Convert V1 response to V2 format"""
        return cls(
            id=v1_response.id,
            status=v1_response.status,
            total=v1_response.total,
            currency="USD",  # Default for legacy data
            items=v1_response.items
        )

# Version 3: Breaking changes with new structure
class OrderResponseV3(BaseModel):
    order_id: str  # Renamed field
    order_status: OrderStatus  # Changed to enum
    pricing: OrderPricing  # Nested object
    line_items: List[OrderLineItem]  # Structured items

    @classmethod
    def from_v2(cls, v2_response: OrderResponseV2) -> 'OrderResponseV3':
        """Convert V2 response to V3 format"""
        return cls(
            order_id=v2_response.id,
            order_status=OrderStatus(v2_response.status),
            pricing=OrderPricing(
                total=v2_response.total,
                currency=v2_response.currency
            ),
            line_items=[
                OrderLineItem(**item) for item in v2_response.items
            ]
        )

class VersionedOrderController:
    """Controller that supports multiple API versions"""

    def __init__(self, order_service: OrderService):
        self.order_service = order_service

    @router.get("/orders/{order_id}")
    async def get_order(
        self,
        order_id: str,
        version: APIVersion = APIVersion.V3,
        accept_version: Optional[str] = Header(None)
    ) -> Union[OrderResponseV1, OrderResponseV2, OrderResponseV3]:

        # Determine version from header or parameter
        requested_version = self._determine_version(version, accept_version)

        # Get order from service (version-agnostic)
        order = await self.order_service.get_order(order_id)
        if not order:
            raise HTTPException(status_code=404, detail="Order not found")

        # Convert to appropriate response format
        return self._format_response(order, requested_version)

    def _determine_version(
        self, 
        version_param: APIVersion, 
        accept_header: Optional[str]
    ) -> APIVersion:
        """Determine API version from various sources"""

        if accept_header:
            # Parse from Accept header: application/json; version=2.0
            if "version=1.0" in accept_header:
                return APIVersion.V1
            elif "version=2.0" in accept_header:
                return APIVersion.V2
            elif "version=3.0" in accept_header:
                return APIVersion.V3

        return version_param

    def _format_response(
        self, 
        order: Order, 
        version: APIVersion
    ) -> Union[OrderResponseV1, OrderResponseV2, OrderResponseV3]:
        """Format order response for requested API version"""

        if version == APIVersion.V1:
            return OrderResponseV1(
                id=str(order.id),
                status=order.status.value,
                total=float(order.total_amount.amount),
                items=[item.to_dict() for item in order.items]
            )

        elif version == APIVersion.V2:
            return OrderResponseV2(
                id=str(order.id),
                status=order.status.value,
                total=float(order.total_amount.amount),
                currency=order.total_amount.currency,
                items=[item.to_dict() for item in order.items],
                shipping_address=order.shipping_address.to_dict() if order.shipping_address else None
            )

        else:  # V3
            return OrderResponseV3(
                order_id=str(order.id),
                order_status=order.status,
                pricing=OrderPricing(
                    total=order.total_amount.amount,
                    currency=order.total_amount.currency
                ),
                line_items=[
                    OrderLineItem.from_domain(item) for item in order.items
                ]
            )

    Pattern 4: Infrastructure Evolution

    Infrastructure should evolve to meet changing operational requirements without disrupting business logic.

    # Evolution from simple to sophisticated infrastructure
class InfrastructureEvolution:

    # Phase 1: Simple Deployment
    class SimpleDeployment:
        """Single server deployment for initial launch"""

        def __init__(self):
            self.database = PostgreSQLDatabase("localhost:5432")
            self.cache = InMemoryCache()
            self.logger = ConsoleLogger()

    # Phase 2: Scalable Infrastructure
    class ScalableDeployment:
        """Multi-server deployment with load balancing"""

        def __init__(self):
            self.database = PostgreSQLCluster([
                "db-primary:5432",
                "db-replica-1:5432", 
                "db-replica-2:5432"
            ])
            self.cache = RedisCluster([
                "redis-1:6379",
                "redis-2:6379",
                "redis-3:6379"
            ])
            self.logger = StructuredLogger(
                output=CloudWatchLogsHandler()
            )

    # Phase 3: Cloud-Native Infrastructure
    class CloudNativeDeployment:
        """Fully cloud-native with auto-scaling and monitoring"""

        def __init__(self):
            self.database = AWSRDSProxy(
                cluster_endpoint="cluster.amazonaws.com",
                read_replicas=["reader-1.amazonaws.com"],
                auto_scaling=True
            )
            self.cache = AWSElastiCache(
                cluster_mode=True,
                auto_failover=True
            )
            self.search = AWSElasticsearch(
                domain="order-search-domain"
            )
            self.logger = AWSCloudWatchLogger(
                log_group="/aws/application/orders",
                structured=True,
                sampling_rate=0.1  # Sample 10% of logs
            )
            self.metrics = AWSCloudWatchMetrics()
            self.tracing = AWSXRayTracing()

# Configuration-driven infrastructure selection
class InfrastructureFactory:
    """Factory to create infrastructure based on environment configuration"""

    @staticmethod
    def create_infrastructure(config: InfrastructureConfig):
        if config.environment == "development":
            return InfrastructureEvolution.SimpleDeployment()
        elif config.environment == "staging":
            return InfrastructureEvolution.ScalableDeployment()
        elif config.environment == "production":
            return InfrastructureEvolution.CloudNativeDeployment()
        else:
            raise ValueError(f"Unknown environment: {config.environment}")

    Managing Technical Debt During Evolution

    Technical debt is inevitable during architectural evolution. The key is managing it strategically:

    # Technical Debt Tracking and Management
from dataclasses import dataclass
from enum import Enum
from typing import List, Optional
from datetime import datetime, timedelta

class TechnicalDebtSeverity(Enum):
    LOW = "low"
    MEDIUM = "medium"
    HIGH = "high"
    CRITICAL = "critical"

@dataclass
class TechnicalDebt:
    id: str
    description: str
    severity: TechnicalDebtSeverity
    affected_components: List[str]
    estimated_effort_days: int
    business_impact: str
    created_date: datetime
    target_resolution_date: Optional[datetime] = None

class TechnicalDebtManager:
    """Manages technical debt during architectural evolution"""

    def __init__(self):
        self.debt_items: Dict[str, TechnicalDebt] = {}
        self.resolution_strategies = {}

    def add_debt(self, debt: TechnicalDebt):
        """Add new technical debt item"""
        self.debt_items[debt.id] = debt
        self._schedule_resolution(debt)

    def prioritize_debt(self) -> List[TechnicalDebt]:
        """Prioritize debt items by business impact and severity"""
        return sorted(
            self.debt_items.values(),
            key=lambda d: (
                d.severity.value,
                len(d.affected_components),
                d.estimated_effort_days
            ),
            reverse=True
        )

    def create_migration_plan(
        self, 
        target_architecture: str,
        available_capacity_days: int
    ) -> MigrationPlan:
        """Create plan to address debt while evolving architecture"""

        prioritized_debt = self.prioritize_debt()
        plan = MigrationPlan(target_architecture)

        remaining_capacity = available_capacity_days

        for debt_item in prioritized_debt:
            if debt_item.estimated_effort_days <= remaining_capacity:
                plan.add_debt_resolution(debt_item)
                remaining_capacity -= debt_item.estimated_effort_days
            else:
                plan.add_deferred_debt(debt_item)

        return plan

    def _schedule_resolution(self, debt: TechnicalDebt):
        """Schedule debt resolution based on severity"""
        now = datetime.now()

        if debt.severity == TechnicalDebtSeverity.CRITICAL:
            debt.target_resolution_date = now + timedelta(weeks=1)
        elif debt.severity == TechnicalDebtSeverity.HIGH:
            debt.target_resolution_date = now + timedelta(weeks=4)
        elif debt.severity == TechnicalDebtSeverity.MEDIUM:
            debt.target_resolution_date = now + timedelta(weeks=12)
        else:
            debt.target_resolution_date = now + timedelta(weeks=26)

# Example usage during evolution
def evolve_order_service():
    """Example of managed evolution with debt tracking"""

    debt_manager = TechnicalDebtManager()

    # Identify debt during evolution
    debt_manager.add_debt(TechnicalDebt(
        id="legacy-payment-integration",
        description="Legacy payment service uses synchronous calls without retries",
        severity=TechnicalDebtSeverity.HIGH,
        affected_components=["OrderService", "PaymentService"],
        estimated_effort_days=5,
        business_impact="Payment failures cause order loss",
        created_date=datetime.now()
    ))

    debt_manager.add_debt(TechnicalDebt(
        id="missing-integration-tests",
        description="Order processing flow lacks comprehensive integration tests",
        severity=TechnicalDebtSeverity.MEDIUM,
        affected_components=["OrderService", "InventoryService", "PaymentService"],
        estimated_effort_days=8,
        business_impact="Deployment risk increases with each change",
        created_date=datetime.now()
    ))

    # Create migration plan
    plan = debt_manager.create_migration_plan(
        target_architecture="microservices",
        available_capacity_days=20
    )

    return plan

    Evolution Monitoring and Metrics

    Track the health of your architectural evolution with key metrics:

    # Evolution Health Metrics
class ArchitecturalMetrics:
    """Metrics to track architectural evolution health"""

    def __init__(self, metrics_collector):
        self.metrics = metrics_collector

    def track_coupling_metrics(self):
        """Track coupling between components"""

        # Afferent coupling (incoming dependencies)
        afferent_coupling = self._calculate_afferent_coupling()
        self.metrics.gauge("architecture.afferent_coupling", afferent_coupling)

        # Efferent coupling (outgoing dependencies) 
        efferent_coupling = self._calculate_efferent_coupling()
        self.metrics.gauge("architecture.efferent_coupling", efferent_coupling)

        # Instability (Efferent / (Afferent + Efferent))
        total_coupling = afferent_coupling + efferent_coupling
        instability = efferent_coupling / total_coupling if total_coupling > 0 else 0
        self.metrics.gauge("architecture.instability", instability)

    def track_complexity_metrics(self):
        """Track code complexity trends"""

        # Cyclomatic complexity
        complexity = self._calculate_cyclomatic_complexity()
        self.metrics.gauge("architecture.cyclomatic_complexity", complexity)

        # Lines of code per component
        loc_per_component = self._calculate_loc_per_component()
        for component, loc in loc_per_component.items():
            self.metrics.gauge(f"architecture.loc.{component}", loc)

    def track_test_coverage(self):
        """Track test coverage by architectural layer"""

        coverage = self._calculate_layer_coverage()
        for layer, percentage in coverage.items():
            self.metrics.gauge(f"architecture.test_coverage.{layer}", percentage)

    def track_deployment_metrics(self):
        """Track deployment and operational metrics"""

        # Deployment frequency
        self.metrics.counter("architecture.deployments")

        # Mean time to recovery
        mttr = self._calculate_mttr()
        self.metrics.gauge("architecture.mttr_minutes", mttr)

        # Change failure rate
        failure_rate = self._calculate_change_failure_rate()
        self.metrics.gauge("architecture.change_failure_rate", failure_rate)

class EvolutionDashboard:
    """Dashboard to visualize architectural evolution"""

    def __init__(self, metrics: ArchitecturalMetrics):
        self.metrics = metrics

    def generate_health_report(self) -> Dict[str, Any]:
        """Generate comprehensive architectural health report"""

        return {
            "coupling": {
                "afferent": self.metrics.get_latest("architecture.afferent_coupling"),
                "efferent": self.metrics.get_latest("architecture.efferent_coupling"),
                "instability": self.metrics.get_latest("architecture.instability")
            },
            "complexity": {
                "cyclomatic": self.metrics.get_latest("architecture.cyclomatic_complexity"),
                "loc_trend": self.metrics.get_trend("architecture.total_loc", days=30)
            },
            "quality": {
                "test_coverage": self.metrics.get_latest("architecture.test_coverage.total"),
                "debt_ratio": self._calculate_technical_debt_ratio()
            },
            "operational": {
                "deployment_frequency": self.metrics.get_rate("architecture.deployments"),
                "mttr": self.metrics.get_latest("architecture.mttr_minutes"),
                "change_failure_rate": self.metrics.get_latest("architecture.change_failure_rate")
            }
        }

    Evolution Best Practices

    1. Evolutionary Architecture Principles

    # Fitness Functions for Architectural Evolution
class ArchitecturalFitnessFunction:
    """Automated tests that verify architectural characteristics"""

    def test_dependency_direction(self):
        """Ensure dependencies flow toward the domain layer"""
        violations = []

        # Check that infrastructure doesn't import domain
        domain_imports = self._get_imports_to_domain()
        for module, imports in domain_imports.items():
            if module.startswith('infrastructure.'):
                violations.append(f"Infrastructure module {module} imports domain")

        assert len(violations) == 0, f"Dependency violations: {violations}"

    def test_database_abstraction(self):
        """Ensure business logic doesn't depend on specific database"""
        business_modules = self._get_business_modules()
        for module in business_modules:
            imports = self._get_module_imports(module)
            database_imports = [imp for imp in imports if 'sqlalchemy' in imp or 'django.db' in imp]
            assert len(database_imports) == 0, f"Business module {module} has database dependencies"

    def test_external_service_abstraction(self):
        """Ensure business logic uses interfaces for external services"""
        business_modules = self._get_business_modules()
        for module in business_modules:
            imports = self._get_module_imports(module)
            external_imports = [imp for imp in imports if 'requests' in imp or 'boto3' in imp]
            assert len(external_imports) == 0, f"Business module {module} has external service dependencies"

# Integration with CI/CD
def run_architectural_tests():
    """Run architectural fitness functions in CI/CD pipeline"""
    fitness = ArchitecturalFitnessFunction()

    try:
        fitness.test_dependency_direction()
        fitness.test_database_abstraction()
        fitness.test_external_service_abstraction()
        print("‚úÖ All architectural tests passed")
        return True
    except AssertionError as e:
        print(f"‚ùå Architectural test failed: {e}")
        return False

    2. Feature Toggle Strategy

    # Feature Toggles for Safe Evolution
class FeatureToggleManager:
    """Manages feature toggles during architectural evolution"""

    def __init__(self, toggle_store):
        self.toggle_store = toggle_store

    async def is_enabled(
        self, 
        feature: str, 
        context: Optional[Dict[str, Any]] = None
    ) -> bool:
        """Check if feature is enabled for given context"""

        toggle = await self.toggle_store.get_toggle(feature)
        if not toggle:
            return False

        return toggle.evaluate(context or {})

class EvolutionFeatureToggle:
    """Specific toggle for architectural evolution features"""

    def __init__(self, name: str, rollout_percentage: int = 0):
        self.name = name
        self.rollout_percentage = rollout_percentage
        self.enabled_users = set()
        self.enabled_tenants = set()

    def evaluate(self, context: Dict[str, Any]) -> bool:
        """Evaluate if toggle should be enabled for context"""

        user_id = context.get('user_id')
        tenant_id = context.get('tenant_id')

        # Explicit enable lists
        if user_id in self.enabled_users:
            return True
        if tenant_id in self.enabled_tenants:
            return True

        # Percentage rollout
        if self.rollout_percentage > 0:
            hash_input = f"{self.name}:{user_id}:{tenant_id}"
            hash_value = hash(hash_input) % 100
            return hash_value < self.rollout_percentage

        return False

# Usage in evolved architecture
class OrderServiceRouter:
    """Routes between old and new implementations based on toggles"""

    def __init__(
        self,
        legacy_service: LegacyOrderService,
        modern_service: ModernOrderService,
        toggle_manager: FeatureToggleManager
    ):
        self.legacy_service = legacy_service
        self.modern_service = modern_service
        self.toggle_manager = toggle_manager

    async def create_order(self, order_request, user_context):
        """Route order creation based on feature toggles"""

        # Check various evolution toggles
        use_modern_service = await self.toggle_manager.is_enabled(
            "modern_order_service",
            context={'user_id': user_context.user_id, 'tenant_id': user_context.tenant_id}
        )

        use_event_sourcing = await self.toggle_manager.is_enabled(
            "order_event_sourcing",
            context=user_context.to_dict()
        )

        if use_modern_service:
            if use_event_sourcing:
                # Use fully evolved implementation
                return await self.modern_service.create_order_with_events(order_request)
            else:
                # Use modern service with traditional persistence
                return await self.modern_service.create_order(order_request)
        else:
            # Fall back to legacy implementation
            return await self.legacy_service.create_order(order_request)

    Conclusion: Evolution as a Competitive Advantage

    Architectural evolution isn't just about managing technical complexity‚Äîit's a competitive advantage that enables your business to adapt faster than competitors constrained by rigid architectures.

    Key principles for successful evolution:

    1. Business Logic Stability: Preserve your core business investments while infrastructure evolves
    2. Incremental Migration: Use patterns like Strangler Fig to evolve systems gradually
    3. Interface Design: Create abstractions that anticipate future scaling needs
    4. Debt Management: Track and strategically address technical debt
    5. Monitoring Evolution: Use metrics to ensure architectural changes improve system health
    6. Safety Mechanisms: Feature toggles and fitness functions provide guardrails during evolution

    The clean-py repository demonstrates these patterns in action, providing a foundation that can evolve from startup MVP to enterprise scale without requiring complete rewrites.

    The companies that thrive long-term are those that build evolution into their DNA from day one. They understand that the first version of their architecture won't be the last, and they design for change rather than perfection.

    Start with Clean Architecture principles, implement evolution-friendly patterns, and build systems that grow with your business rather than constraining it. Your future self‚Äîand your business‚Äîwill thank you when you're scaling to millions of users instead of rewriting everything from scratch.

    Architecture evolution is not just about technology‚Äîit's about building organizational capability to adapt and thrive in an uncertain future.

    The Hidden Complexity of Estimating Cloud Egress Costs

    This post was inspired by my attempt to build an aws-egress-estimate tool‚Äîa project that ultimately proved just how complex and nearly impossible accurate egress estimation truly is.

    When I first started working with cloud infrastructure, I thought estimating costs would be straightforward. CPU hours, storage, memory‚Äîthese seemed like simple metrics to track and predict. Then I encountered egress charges, and everything changed. What appeared to be a minor line item in the billing documentation turned into one of the most unpredictable aspects of cloud cost management.

    Why Egress Estimation Feels Like Fortune Telling

    Egress costs represent charges for data leaving your cloud environment. Sounds simple enough, right? The reality is far more nuanced. Unlike compute resources that you provision explicitly, egress happens as a consequence of your architecture, your users' behavior, and the intricate dance between your services.

    graph LR subgraph "Cloud Environment" A[Application] --> B[Database] A --> C[Cache] A --> D[Storage] end A -->|$$$| E[Internet/Users] A -->|$$$| F[Other Regions] A -->|$$$| G[External APIs] D -->|$$$| H[Backup Location] class A,B,C,D internal class E,F,G,H egress classDef internal fill:#4a90e2,stroke:#2c5aa0,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff classDef egress fill:#e74c3c,stroke:#c0392b,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff

    The fundamental challenge isn't just about measuring data volume. It's about predicting how data will flow through a system that's constantly evolving. Every new feature, every architectural change, every shift in user behavior can dramatically alter your egress patterns. I've seen teams add what they thought was a minor feature‚Äîa new image processing endpoint‚Äîonly to watch their egress costs triple because they didn't account for CDN cache misses on dynamically generated content.

    The Interconnection Maze

    Modern cloud architectures rarely exist in isolation. Your typical application might span multiple availability zones, regions, or even cloud providers. Each boundary crossed represents a potential egress charge, and these boundaries aren't always obvious.

    Consider a seemingly simple microservices architecture. Service A talks to Service B, which queries a database, calls an external API, and returns data to Service A. Now multiply this by dozens of services, add in service mesh sidecars, observability agents, and backup systems. Each connection potentially crosses a billing boundary. The result? A web of data flows that would make even the most patient network engineer reach for a strong coffee.

    graph TD subgraph AZ1[Availability Zone 1] SA[Service A] SB[Service B] end subgraph AZ2[Availability Zone 2] SC[Service C] DB[(Database)] end subgraph Region2[Region 2] SD[Service D] BK[(Backup)] end subgraph External API[External API] MON[Monitoring] end SA -.->|Free| SB SA -->|$ Cross-AZ| SC SB -->|$ Cross-AZ| DB SC -->|$$$ Cross-Region| SD DB -->|$$$ Cross-Region| BK SA -->|$$$ Internet| API SA -->|$$$ Internet| MON SB -->|$$$ Internet| MON SC -->|$$$ Internet| MON class SA,SB,SC,DB,SD,BK services class API,MON external classDef services fill:#27ae60,stroke:#229954,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff classDef external fill:#e67e22,stroke:#d35400,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff

    The real kicker is that these interconnections often grow organically. Teams add services, integrate third-party tools, and implement new features without always considering the cumulative effect on data transfer costs. I've worked with companies that discovered their logging infrastructure was generating more egress charges than their actual application traffic. The logs meant to help them save money were quietly draining their budget.

    The Prediction Paradox

    So, is estimating egress impossible? Not quite, but it requires a different mindset than estimating other cloud resources. You can't simply look at your current usage and multiply by expected growth. Egress patterns are non-linear and often counterintuitive.

    What you can do is build models based on scenarios and ranges rather than precise predictions. Start by mapping your major data flows‚Äîwhere does data enter your system, how does it move between components, and where does it exit? Look for patterns in your existing traffic. Do you see spikes during certain hours? Are there seasonal variations? Understanding these patterns gives you a baseline, even if it's imperfect.

    The key is to embrace uncertainty while building in buffers. I typically recommend teams estimate their egress costs in ranges: optimistic, realistic, and pessimistic scenarios. This approach acknowledges the inherent unpredictability while still providing useful guidance for budgeting and architectural decisions.

    Egress Cost Estimation Scenarios

    Scenario Monthly Data Transfer Estimated Cost Key Assumptions
    Optimistic 500 GB $45 ‚Ä¢ High CDN cache hit rate (90%+)
    ‚Ä¢ Minimal cross-region traffic
    ‚Ä¢ Efficient API usage
    Realistic 2 TB $180 ‚Ä¢ Moderate CDN cache hits (70%)
    ‚Ä¢ Some cross-region replication
    ‚Ä¢ Normal monitoring overhead
    Pessimistic 5 TB $450 ‚Ä¢ Poor cache performance (40%)
    ‚Ä¢ Significant cross-region traffic
    ‚Ä¢ Verbose logging/monitoring
    Worst Case 10 TB $900+ ‚Ä¢ Cache failures
    ‚Ä¢ Unoptimized APIs
    ‚Ä¢ Data transfer storms

    Gotchas That Keep Engineers Up at Night

    Through years of cloud cost investigations, I've encountered numerous egress-related surprises that teams consistently miss:

    flowchart LR subgraph Hidden["Hidden Egress Sources"] direction TB DB[Database<br/>Replication] BK[Backup<br/>Pipeline] API[API Gateway<br/>Amplification] LOG[Monitoring &<br/>Logging] CDN[CDN Cache<br/>Misses] end subgraph Impact["Cost Impact"] direction TB LOW["$ Low<br/>(< $100/mo)"] MED["$$ Medium<br/>($100-1000/mo)"] HIGH["$$$ High<br/>(> $1000/mo)"] end DB --> HIGH BK --> MED API --> HIGH LOG --> MED CDN --> HIGH class DB,API,CDN highCost class BK,LOG medCost class HIGH critical class MED warning class LOW normal classDef highCost fill:#c0392b,stroke:#a93226,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff classDef medCost fill:#d68910,stroke:#b9770e,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff classDef critical fill:#922b21,stroke:#7b241c,stroke-width:3px,color:#fff classDef warning fill:#af601a,stroke:#935116,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff classDef normal fill:#239b56,stroke:#1e8449,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff

    The Cross-Region Database Replication Trap: Many teams set up multi-region deployments for reliability without realizing that database replication between regions generates substantial egress charges. That real-time sync keeping your disaster recovery site updated? It's essentially a 24/7 egress generator.

    The Forgotten Backup Pipeline: Automated backups to external storage or different regions create predictable but often overlooked egress costs. Teams budget for storage but forget about the transfer costs, especially when they implement aggressive backup strategies with multiple daily snapshots.

    The API Gateway Amplification Effect: Public APIs can become egress multipliers. One external request might trigger dozens of internal service calls, each potentially crossing network boundaries. A popular API endpoint can turn into a significant cost center if the internal data flows aren't optimized.

    The Monitoring and Logging Vortex: Comprehensive observability is crucial, but shipping logs and metrics to external services or different regions adds up quickly. I've seen cases where verbose logging in production environments generated more egress charges than the actual application serving users.

    The CDN Cache Miss Penalty: CDNs are supposed to reduce egress costs by serving content from edge locations. But if your cache hit ratio is poor‚Äîdue to unique query parameters, personalized content, or incorrect cache headers‚Äîyou might actually increase your egress costs as the CDN repeatedly fetches content from your origin servers.

    Building a Pragmatic Approach

    Given these challenges, how should teams approach egress estimation? Start with visibility. You can't optimize what you can't measure. Implement comprehensive tagging and use cloud provider tools to track data transfer costs by service, team, and purpose.

    Next, architect with egress in mind. Colocate chatty services in the same availability zone. Use regional endpoints where possible. Implement smart caching strategies. These decisions, made early, can prevent significant costs down the line.

    Finally, treat egress costs as a first-class metric in your architecture reviews. When proposing new features or services, include data transfer patterns in the design documentation. Ask questions like: Where will this data come from? Where will it go? How often will this transfer happen?

    Egress Cost Optimization Action Plan

    • [ ] Audit Current Architecture
    • [ ] Map all service-to-service communications
    • [ ] Identify cross-AZ and cross-region traffic
    • [ ] Document external API dependencies

    • [ ] Review backup and replication strategies

    • [ ] Implement Monitoring

    • [ ] Enable detailed billing reports with cost allocation tags
    • [ ] Set up alerts for unusual egress spikes
    • [ ] Create dashboards for data transfer metrics

    • [ ] Track CDN cache hit ratios

    • [ ] Optimize Architecture

    • [ ] Colocate chatty services in same AZ
    • [ ] Implement request batching for external APIs
    • [ ] Configure appropriate CDN cache headers

    • [ ] Review and optimize logging verbosity

    • [ ] Establish Governance

    • [ ] Create data transfer budget per team/service
    • [ ] Include egress estimates in design reviews
    • [ ] Document egress patterns in architecture decisions
    • [ ] Regular quarterly egress cost reviews

    The Path Forward

    Estimating egress costs perfectly might be impossible, but that doesn't mean we should throw our hands up in defeat. Like many aspects of distributed systems, it's about managing complexity and uncertainty rather than eliminating them entirely.

    The teams that succeed are those that acknowledge the challenge, build observable systems, and create feedback loops that allow them to adjust quickly when reality diverges from their estimates. They don't aim for perfect predictions but rather for sustainable architectures that can evolve without creating budget surprises.

    Cloud egress costs reflect the fundamental complexity of modern distributed systems. By understanding the challenges, recognizing the common pitfalls, and building pragmatic estimation models, we can at least make these costs predictable enough to plan around‚Äîeven if we can't predict them down to the last byte.

    AWS Deployment Patterns: ECS Fargate vs Lambda for Python Services

    Choosing the right AWS deployment pattern for your Python microservices can make the difference between a system that scales seamlessly and one that becomes a maintenance nightmare. The decision between ECS Fargate and Lambda isn't just about compute models‚Äîit's about matching your application architecture to the right infrastructure patterns for optimal performance, cost, and operational overhead.

    The clean-py repository demonstrates both deployment patterns with production-ready configurations. This isn't theoretical comparison‚Äîit's practical guidance based on real-world deployments managing millions of requests per day.

    The Deployment Decision Framework

    I've deployed the same Clean Architecture Python application on both ECS Fargate and Lambda across different organizations. Each pattern has distinct advantages that align with specific use cases:

    ECS Fargate excels when you need: - Consistent long-running processes - Complex application state management - Full control over the runtime environment - Traditional microservices patterns - Predictable traffic patterns

    Lambda shines when you have: - Event-driven architectures - Irregular or spikey traffic - Simple, stateless operations - Cost optimization as a primary concern - Rapid scaling requirements

    A recent project illustrated this perfectly. We migrated an e-commerce platform from a monolithic architecture to Clean Architecture microservices. The order processing service handles steady traffic and maintains complex business logic‚Äîperfect for ECS Fargate. The notification service processes events irregularly with high burst requirements‚Äîideal for Lambda.

    The key insight: don't choose one pattern for everything. Use the right tool for each service's specific requirements.

    ECS Fargate: Container-Based Microservices

    ECS Fargate provides the traditional microservices experience with AWS-managed infrastructure. Your Python applications run in containers with predictable resource allocation and persistent connections.

    Fargate Architecture Pattern

    ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê    ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê    ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
