    Dockerized Clean Architecture Application

    The clean-py repository includes production-ready Docker configurations:

    # Dockerfile
FROM python:3.11-slim as base

# Set environment variables
ENV PYTHONUNBUFFERED=1 \
    PYTHONDONTWRITEBYTECODE=1 \
    PIP_NO_CACHE_DIR=1 \
    PIP_DISABLE_PIP_VERSION_CHECK=1

# Install system dependencies
RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y \
    gcc \
    libc6-dev \
    && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

# Create app user
RUN groupadd -r app && useradd -r -g app app

WORKDIR /app

# Install Python dependencies
COPY requirements.txt .
RUN pip install --no-deps -r requirements.txt

# Copy application code
COPY src/ src/
COPY alembic/ alembic/
COPY alembic.ini .

# Set ownership
RUN chown -R app:app /app
USER app

# Health check
HEALTHCHECK --interval=30s --timeout=5s --start-period=60s --retries=3 \
    CMD python -c "import requests; requests.get('http://localhost:8000/health')"

# Production stage
FROM base as production

# Copy only necessary files for production
COPY --from=base --chown=app:app /app /app

EXPOSE 8000

# Use Gunicorn for production
CMD ["gunicorn", "src.presentation.main:app", \
     "--worker-class", "uvicorn.workers.UvicornWorker", \
     "--workers", "4", \
     "--bind", "0.0.0.0:8000", \
     "--access-logfile", "-", \
     "--error-logfile", "-", \
     "--log-level", "info"]

# Development stage
FROM base as development

# Install development dependencies
COPY requirements-dev.txt .
RUN pip install --no-deps -r requirements-dev.txt

# Install application in development mode
RUN pip install -e .

CMD ["uvicorn", "src.presentation.main:app", \
     "--host", "0.0.0.0", \
     "--port", "8000", \
     "--reload"]

    Infrastructure as Code Options

    When deploying to AWS, you have several Infrastructure as Code (IaC) options. Each has its place in the development lifecycle:

    CloudFormation is AWS's native IaC service, perfect for prototyping and experimentation. Its declarative YAML/JSON format makes it easy to understand, and most importantly, it provides simple cleanup‚Äîdelete the stack and everything is gone. This makes CloudFormation ideal for development environments where you're iterating quickly:

    # cloudformation/prototype-stack.yaml
# Great for prototyping - easy to create and tear down
AWSTemplateFormatVersion: '2010-09-09'
Description: Prototype ECS Fargate stack for clean-py

Parameters:
  EnvironmentName:
    Type: String
    Default: prototype
    Description: Environment name prefix

Resources:
  # Simple ECS cluster for testing
  ECSCluster:
    Type: AWS::ECS::Cluster
    Properties:
      ClusterName: !Sub ${EnvironmentName}-cluster

  # Task definition
  TaskDefinition:
    Type: AWS::ECS::TaskDefinition
    Properties:
      Family: !Sub ${EnvironmentName}-task
      NetworkMode: awsvpc
      RequiresCompatibilities: [FARGATE]
      Cpu: '256'
      Memory: '512'
      ContainerDefinitions:
        - Name: app
          Image: !Sub ${AWS::AccountId}.dkr.ecr.${AWS::Region}.amazonaws.com/clean-py:latest
          PortMappings:
            - ContainerPort: 8000

  # Quick cleanup with: aws cloudformation delete-stack --stack-name prototype-stack

    For production environments, however, you'll want more sophisticated tools:

    AWS CDK (Cloud Development Kit) lets you define infrastructure using familiar programming languages. This is the recommended approach for production Python applications‚Äîyou can use Python to define your Python application's infrastructure:

    # infrastructure/ecs_stack.py
from aws_cdk import (
    Stack,
    aws_ecs as ecs,
    aws_ec2 as ec2,
    aws_elasticloadbalancingv2 as elbv2,
    aws_logs as logs,
    aws_secretsmanager as secretsmanager,
    aws_iam as iam,
    Duration
)

class CleanPyECSStack(Stack):
    def __init__(self, scope, construct_id, **kwargs):
        super().__init__(scope, construct_id, **kwargs)

        # VPC
        vpc = ec2.Vpc(
            self, "CleanPyVPC",
            max_azs=2,
            nat_gateways=1,
            enable_dns_hostnames=True,
            enable_dns_support=True
        )

        # ECS Cluster
        cluster = ecs.Cluster(
            self, "CleanPyCluster",
            vpc=vpc,
            enable_fargate_capacity_providers=True
        )

        # Task Definition
        task_definition = ecs.FargateTaskDefinition(
            self, "OrderServiceTaskDef",
            memory_limit_mib=1024,
            cpu=512
        )

        # Add container
        container = task_definition.add_container(
            "OrderServiceContainer",
            image=ecs.ContainerImage.from_registry("your-registry/clean-py:latest"),
            logging=ecs.LogDrivers.aws_logs(
                stream_prefix="order-service",
                log_retention=logs.RetentionDays.ONE_WEEK
            ),
            environment={
                "AWS_REGION": self.region,
                "ENVIRONMENT": "production"
            },
            secrets={
                "DATABASE_URL": ecs.Secret.from_secrets_manager(
                    secretsmanager.Secret.from_secret_name(
                        self, "DatabaseSecret", "clean-py/database"
                    )
                )
            }
        )

        container.add_port_mappings(
            ecs.PortMapping(container_port=8000)
        )

        # Security Group
        security_group = ec2.SecurityGroup(
            self, "OrderServiceSG",
            vpc=vpc,
            description="Security group for Order Service"
        )
        security_group.add_ingress_rule(
            ec2.Peer.any_ipv4(),
            ec2.Port.tcp(8000),
            "Allow HTTP traffic"
        )

        # ECS Service
        service = ecs.FargateService(
            self, "OrderService",
            cluster=cluster,
            task_definition=task_definition,
            desired_count=2,
            security_groups=[security_group],
            enable_logging=True,
            health_check_grace_period=Duration.seconds(60)
        )

        # Application Load Balancer
        alb = elbv2.ApplicationLoadBalancer(
            self, "OrderServiceALB",
            vpc=vpc,
            internet_facing=True
        )

        # Target Group
        target_group = elbv2.ApplicationTargetGroup(
            self, "OrderServiceTargets",
            port=8000,
            vpc=vpc,
            target_type=elbv2.TargetType.IP,
            health_check_path="/health",
            health_check_interval=Duration.seconds(30)
        )

        # Listener
        listener = alb.add_listener(
            "OrderServiceListener",
            port=80,
            default_target_groups=[target_group]
        )

        # Auto Scaling
        scaling = service.auto_scale_task_count(max_capacity=10, min_capacity=2)
        scaling.scale_on_cpu_utilization(
            "CpuScaling",
            target_utilization_percent=70,
            scale_in_cooldown=Duration.seconds(300),
            scale_out_cooldown=Duration.seconds(60)
        )

        scaling.scale_on_memory_utilization(
            "MemoryScaling",
            target_utilization_percent=80
        )

    Terraform is another excellent production choice, especially if you're working with multiple cloud providers or prefer a cloud-agnostic approach. Its declarative HCL (HashiCorp Configuration Language) syntax and powerful state management make it ideal for complex production deployments:

    # infrastructure/ecs.tf
# Terraform - production-grade with state management
terraform {
  required_providers {
    aws = {
      source  = "hashicorp/aws"
      version = "~> 5.0"
    }
  }

  backend "s3" {
    bucket = "terraform-state-bucket"
    key    = "clean-py/ecs/terraform.tfstate"
    region = "us-west-2"
  }
}

resource "aws_ecs_cluster" "main" {
  name = "${var.environment}-clean-py-cluster"

  setting {
    name  = "containerInsights"
    value = "enabled"
  }
}

resource "aws_ecs_task_definition" "app" {
  family                   = "${var.environment}-clean-py"
  network_mode            = "awsvpc"
  requires_compatibilities = ["FARGATE"]
  cpu                     = var.task_cpu
  memory                  = var.task_memory

  container_definitions = jsonencode([
    {
      name  = "clean-py"
      image = "${var.ecr_repository_url}:${var.image_tag}"

      portMappings = [
        {
          containerPort = 8000
          protocol      = "tcp"
        }
      ]

      environment = [
        {
          name  = "ENVIRONMENT"
          value = var.environment
        }
      ]

      secrets = [
        {
          name      = "DATABASE_URL"
          valueFrom = aws_secretsmanager_secret.database_url.arn
        }
      ]

      logConfiguration = {
        logDriver = "awslogs"
        options = {
          awslogs-group         = aws_cloudwatch_log_group.ecs.name
          awslogs-region        = var.aws_region
          awslogs-stream-prefix = "ecs"
        }
      }
    }
  ])
}

# Terraform advantages:
# - Detailed plan before apply
# - State management and locking
# - Import existing resources
# - Multi-cloud support

    Choosing Your IaC Tool

    Tool Best For Advantages Considerations
    CloudFormation Prototyping, experiments ‚Ä¢ Native AWS
    ‚Ä¢ Easy cleanup
    ‚Ä¢ No additional tools
    ‚Ä¢ Stack rollback    		 ‚Ä¢ Verbose syntax
    ‚Ä¢ Limited programming constructs
    ‚Ä¢ AWS-only
    CDK Production AWS apps ‚Ä¢ Use Python/TypeScript
    ‚Ä¢ Type safety
    ‚Ä¢ High-level constructs
    ‚Ä¢ Generates CloudFormation    		 ‚Ä¢ AWS-only
    ‚Ä¢ Requires CDK toolkit
    ‚Ä¢ Learning curve
    Terraform Multi-cloud production ‚Ä¢ Cloud agnostic
    ‚Ä¢ Mature ecosystem
    ‚Ä¢ State management
    ‚Ä¢ Resource import    		 ‚Ä¢ Separate language (HCL)
    ‚Ä¢ State file management
    ‚Ä¢ Provider versioning

    For the clean-py project, I recommend: 1. Start with CloudFormation for initial prototyping‚Äîit's simple and cleanup is trivial 2. Move to CDK for production AWS deployments‚Äîuse Python to define Python infrastructure 3. Consider Terraform if you need multi-cloud support or have existing Terraform expertise

    The key insight: don't overthink the IaC choice initially. Start with CloudFormation to validate your architecture, then migrate to CDK or Terraform once you understand your requirements. The clean-py patterns work with all three approaches. 

    ### ECS Deployment Pipeline

```yaml
# .github/workflows/ecs-deploy.yml
name: Deploy to ECS Fargate

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
    paths: ['src/**']

env:
  AWS_REGION: us-west-2
  ECR_REPOSITORY: clean-py
  ECS_SERVICE: order-service
  ECS_CLUSTER: clean-py-cluster
  CONTAINER_NAME: order-service

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
    - name: Checkout
      uses: actions/checkout@v3

    - name: Configure AWS credentials
      uses: aws-actions/configure-aws-credentials@v2
      with:
        aws-access-key-id: ${{ secrets.AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID }}
        aws-secret-access-key: ${{ secrets.AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY }}
        aws-region: ${{ env.AWS_REGION }}

    - name: Login to Amazon ECR
      id: login-ecr
      uses: aws-actions/amazon-ecr-login@v1

    - name: Build, tag, and push image to Amazon ECR
      id: build-image
      env:
        ECR_REGISTRY: ${{ steps.login-ecr.outputs.registry }}
        IMAGE_TAG: ${{ github.sha }}
      run: |
        docker build -t $ECR_REGISTRY/$ECR_REPOSITORY:$IMAGE_TAG .
        docker push $ECR_REGISTRY/$ECR_REPOSITORY:$IMAGE_TAG
        echo "image=$ECR_REGISTRY/$ECR_REPOSITORY:$IMAGE_TAG" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT

    - name: Download task definition
      run: |
        aws ecs describe-task-definition \
          --task-definition clean-py-order-service \
          --query taskDefinition > task-definition.json

    - name: Fill in the new image ID in the Amazon ECS task definition
      id: task-def
      uses: aws-actions/amazon-ecs-render-task-definition@v1
      with:
        task-definition: task-definition.json
        container-name: ${{ env.CONTAINER_NAME }}
        image: ${{ steps.build-image.outputs.image }}

    - name: Deploy Amazon ECS task definition
      uses: aws-actions/amazon-ecs-deploy-task-definition@v1
      with:
        task-definition: ${{ steps.task-def.outputs.task-definition }}
        service: ${{ env.ECS_SERVICE }}
        cluster: ${{ env.ECS_CLUSTER }}
        wait-for-service-stability: true

    AWS Lambda: Serverless Event-Driven Architecture

    Lambda deployment patterns work best for event-driven services with irregular traffic patterns. The clean-py repository includes Lambda-optimized configurations for specific use cases.

    Lambda Architecture Pattern

    ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê    ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê    ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
‚îÇ   API Gateway   ‚îÇ    ‚îÇ  Lambda Function‚îÇ    ‚îÇ   Event Sources ‚îÇ
‚îÇ                 ‚îÇ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚ñ∂‚îÇ                 ‚îÇ‚óÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÇ                 ‚îÇ
‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ REST API      ‚îÇ    ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Clean Arch    ‚îÇ    ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ SQS queues    ‚îÇ
‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Authentication‚îÇ    ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Fast startup  ‚îÇ    ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ DynamoDB      ‚îÇ
‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Rate limiting ‚îÇ    ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Auto scaling  ‚îÇ    ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ S3 events     ‚îÇ
‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Request/Response‚îÇ  ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Pay per use   ‚îÇ    ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ EventBridge   ‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
                                ‚îÇ                       ‚îÇ
                       ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê    ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
                       ‚îÇ   CloudWatch    ‚îÇ    ‚îÇ   Parameter     ‚îÇ
                       ‚îÇ                 ‚îÇ    ‚îÇ   Store         ‚îÇ
                       ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Metrics       ‚îÇ    ‚îÇ                 ‚îÇ
                       ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Logs          ‚îÇ    ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Configuration ‚îÇ
                       ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ X-Ray traces  ‚îÇ    ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Secrets       ‚îÇ
                       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò    ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Environment   ‚îÇ
                                              ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò

    Lambda-Optimized Application Structure

    # src/presentation/lambda_handlers/order_handler.py
import json
import asyncio
from typing import Dict, Any
from aws_lambda_powertools import Logger, Tracer, Metrics
from aws_lambda_powertools.logging import correlation_paths
from aws_lambda_powertools.metrics import MetricUnit

from ...infrastructure.logging.lambda_utils import configure_lambda_logging
from ...infrastructure.dependencies import get_container
from ...application.use_cases.orders.create_order import CreateOrderUseCase
from ...domain.exceptions import DomainException

# Configure observability
logger = Logger()
tracer = Tracer()
metrics = Metrics()

# Configure logging for Lambda
configure_lambda_logging()

# Initialize dependency container (cached across invocations)
container = get_container()

@tracer.capture_lambda_handler
@logger.inject_lambda_context(correlation_id_path=correlation_paths.API_GATEWAY_REST)
@metrics.log_metrics
def lambda_handler(event: Dict[str, Any], context) -> Dict[str, Any]:
    """
    Lambda handler for order creation
    Optimized for API Gateway REST API events
    """

    try:
        # Parse request
        body = json.loads(event.get('body', '{}'))
        headers = event.get('headers', {})
        path_parameters = event.get('pathParameters') or {}
        query_parameters = event.get('queryStringParameters') or {}

        # Extract user context from JWT (set by API Gateway authorizer)
        request_context = event.get('requestContext', {})
        authorizer = request_context.get('authorizer', {})
        user_id = authorizer.get('user_id')

        if not user_id:
            return create_error_response(401, "Authentication required")

        # Route based on HTTP method and path
        http_method = event['httpMethod']
        resource = event['resource']

        if http_method == 'POST' and resource == '/orders':
            return asyncio.run(handle_create_order(body, user_id, context))
        elif http_method == 'GET' and resource == '/orders/{order_id}':
            order_id = path_parameters.get('order_id')
            return asyncio.run(handle_get_order(order_id, user_id, context))
        else:
            return create_error_response(404, "Not found")

    except json.JSONDecodeError:
        logger.error("Invalid JSON in request body")
        return create_error_response(400, "Invalid JSON")
    except Exception as e:
        logger.exception("Unexpected error in Lambda handler")
        metrics.add_metadata(key="error", value=str(e))
        return create_error_response(500, "Internal server error")

@tracer.capture_method
async def handle_create_order(
    order_data: Dict[str, Any], 
    user_id: str, 
    context
) -> Dict[str, Any]:
    """Handle order creation request"""

    try:
        # Get use case from container
        create_order_use_case = container.get(CreateOrderUseCase)

        # Execute use case
        with tracer.provider.get_tracer(__name__).start_as_current_span("create_order_use_case"):
            order = await create_order_use_case.execute(
                user_id=user_id,
                order_data=order_data,
                requesting_user_id=user_id  # Simplified for Lambda
            )

        # Record metrics
        metrics.add_metric(name="OrderCreated", unit=MetricUnit.Count, value=1)
        metrics.add_metadata(key="order_id", value=str(order.id))

        # Return success response
        return {
            'statusCode': 201,
            'headers': {
                'Content-Type': 'application/json',
                'Access-Control-Allow-Origin': '*'
            },
            'body': json.dumps({
                'id': str(order.id),
                'status': order.status.value,
                'total_amount': float(order.total_amount.amount),
                'currency': order.total_amount.currency,
                'created_at': order.created_at.isoformat()
            }, default=str)
        }

    except DomainException as e:
        logger.warning(f"Domain exception: {str(e)}")
        metrics.add_metric(name="OrderCreationFailed", unit=MetricUnit.Count, value=1)
        return create_error_response(400, str(e))

def create_error_response(status_code: int, message: str) -> Dict[str, Any]:
    """Create standardized error response"""
    return {
        'statusCode': status_code,
        'headers': {
            'Content-Type': 'application/json',
            'Access-Control-Allow-Origin': '*'
        },
        'body': json.dumps({
            'error': {
                'message': message,
                'timestamp': datetime.utcnow().isoformat()
            }
        })
    }

    Lambda Deployment Configuration

    # infrastructure/lambda_stack.py
from aws_cdk import (
    Stack,
    aws_lambda as lambda_,
    aws_apigateway as apigateway,
    aws_iam as iam,
    aws_logs as logs,
    Duration
)

class CleanPyLambdaStack(Stack):
    def __init__(self, scope, construct_id, **kwargs):
        super().__init__(scope, construct_id, **kwargs)

        # Lambda Layer for dependencies
        dependencies_layer = lambda_.LayerVersion(
            self, "DependenciesLayer",
            code=lambda_.Code.from_asset("lambda-layer.zip"),
            compatible_runtimes=[lambda_.Runtime.PYTHON_3_11],
            description="Python dependencies for Clean Architecture services"
        )

        # Order Service Lambda Function
        order_function = lambda_.Function(
            self, "OrderFunction",
            runtime=lambda_.Runtime.PYTHON_3_11,
            handler="src.presentation.lambda_handlers.order_handler.lambda_handler",
            code=lambda_.Code.from_asset("src"),
            layers=[dependencies_layer],
            timeout=Duration.seconds(30),
            memory_size=512,
            environment={
                "ENVIRONMENT": "production",
                "AWS_REGION": self.region,
                "POWERTOOLS_SERVICE_NAME": "order-service",
                "LOG_LEVEL": "INFO"
            },
            tracing=lambda_.Tracing.ACTIVE,
            retry_attempts=0  # Disable retries for API Gateway
        )

        # Grant permissions for AWS services
        order_function.add_to_role_policy(
            iam.PolicyStatement(
                effect=iam.Effect.ALLOW,
                actions=[
                    "secretsmanager:GetSecretValue",
                    "ssm:GetParameter",
                    "ssm:GetParameters"
                ],
                resources=["*"]  # Restrict in production
            )
        )

        # API Gateway
        api = apigateway.RestApi(
            self, "OrderAPI",
            rest_api_name="Clean Architecture Order Service",
            description="Order management API using Clean Architecture",
            binary_media_types=["application/octet-stream"],
            default_cors_preflight_options=apigateway.CorsOptions(
                allow_origins=apigateway.Cors.ALL_ORIGINS,
                allow_methods=apigateway.Cors.ALL_METHODS,
                allow_headers=["Content-Type", "Authorization"]
            )
        )

        # Lambda Integration
        lambda_integration = apigateway.LambdaIntegration(
            order_function,
            request_templates={
                "application/json": '{ "statusCode": "200" }'
            }
        )

        # API Resources and Methods
        orders_resource = api.root.add_resource("orders")
        orders_resource.add_method("POST", lambda_integration)
        orders_resource.add_method("GET", lambda_integration)

        order_detail_resource = orders_resource.add_resource("{order_id}")
        order_detail_resource.add_method("GET", lambda_integration)
        order_detail_resource.add_method("PUT", lambda_integration)

        # CloudWatch Log Groups
        lambda_.Function(
            self, "OrderFunctionLogGroup",
            log_retention=logs.RetentionDays.ONE_WEEK
        )

    Lambda Cold Start Optimization

    # src/infrastructure/lambda_optimization.py
import asyncio
import functools
from typing import Any, Callable

# Global connection pool (reused across invocations)
_connection_pool = None
_event_loop = None

def lambda_handler_wrapper(handler: Callable) -> Callable:
    """
    Wrapper to optimize Lambda cold starts and connection reuse
    """
    @functools.wraps(handler)
    def wrapper(event: dict, context) -> Any:
        global _connection_pool, _event_loop

        # Initialize event loop if not exists
        if _event_loop is None:
            _event_loop = asyncio.new_event_loop()
            asyncio.set_event_loop(_event_loop)

        # Initialize connection pool on first invocation
        if _connection_pool is None:
            _connection_pool = initialize_connection_pool()

        # Set connection pool in context for reuse
        context.connection_pool = _connection_pool

        return handler(event, context)

    return wrapper

def initialize_connection_pool():
    """Initialize database connection pool optimized for Lambda"""
    from sqlalchemy.pool import NullPool
    from sqlalchemy import create_engine

    # Use NullPool for Lambda (connections don't persist between invocations)
    engine = create_engine(
        DATABASE_URL,
        poolclass=NullPool,
        connect_args={
            "connect_timeout": 5,
            "command_timeout": 20
        }
    )
    return engine

# Lambda-specific dependency injection
class LambdaDependencyContainer:
    def __init__(self):
        self._instances = {}
        self._initialized = False

    def get(self, service_type):
        if not self._initialized:
            self._initialize()

        if service_type not in self._instances:
            self._instances[service_type] = self._create_instance(service_type)

        return self._instances[service_type]

    def _initialize(self):
        """Initialize heavyweight components once per container lifetime"""
        # Database connections, external service clients, etc.
        self._initialized = True

    def _create_instance(self, service_type):
        """Factory method for service creation"""
        # Implementation depends on your DI framework
        pass

# Global container instance (reused across Lambda invocations)
container = LambdaDependencyContainer()

    Cost Analysis

    # cost_calculator.py - Compare deployment costs
from typing import Dict, Any
from dataclasses import dataclass

@dataclass
class TrafficPattern:
    requests_per_second_avg: float
    requests_per_second_peak: float
    average_response_time_ms: int
    daily_peak_hours: int

def calculate_fargate_cost(
    traffic: TrafficPattern,
    cpu_units: int = 512,  # 0.5 vCPU
    memory_mb: int = 1024,  # 1 GB
    region: str = "us-west-2"
) -> Dict[str, float]:
    """Calculate monthly ECS Fargate costs"""

    # AWS Fargate pricing (as of 2024)
    cpu_price_per_hour = 0.04048  # per vCPU
    memory_price_per_hour = 0.004445  # per GB

    # Calculate required tasks based on traffic
    requests_per_task_per_second = 50  # Assume 50 RPS per task

    avg_tasks = max(1, traffic.requests_per_second_avg / requests_per_task_per_second)
    peak_tasks = max(1, traffic.requests_per_second_peak / requests_per_task_per_second)

    # Task requirements
    vcpu = cpu_units / 1024
    memory_gb = memory_mb / 1024

    # Cost calculation
    cost_per_task_per_hour = (vcpu * cpu_price_per_hour) + (memory_gb * memory_price_per_hour)

    # Average cost (assuming auto-scaling between avg and peak)
    avg_cost_per_hour = avg_tasks * cost_per_task_per_hour
    peak_cost_per_hour = peak_tasks * cost_per_task_per_hour

    # Weighted average (peak hours vs normal hours)
    weighted_hourly_cost = (
        (avg_cost_per_hour * (24 - traffic.daily_peak_hours)) +
        (peak_cost_per_hour * traffic.daily_peak_hours)
    ) / 24

    monthly_cost = weighted_hourly_cost * 24 * 30

    return {
        "monthly_cost": monthly_cost,
        "avg_tasks": avg_tasks,
        "peak_tasks": peak_tasks,
        "cost_breakdown": {
            "cpu": vcpu * cpu_price_per_hour * avg_tasks * 24 * 30,
            "memory": memory_gb * memory_price_per_hour * avg_tasks * 24 * 30
        }
    }

def calculate_lambda_cost(
    traffic: TrafficPattern,
    memory_mb: int = 512,
    region: str = "us-west-2"
) -> Dict[str, float]:
    """Calculate monthly AWS Lambda costs"""

    # Lambda pricing (as of 2024)
    request_price = 0.0000002  # per request
    gb_second_price = 0.0000166667  # per GB-second

    # Calculate monthly requests
    daily_requests = (
        traffic.requests_per_second_avg * (24 - traffic.daily_peak_hours) * 3600 +
        traffic.requests_per_second_peak * traffic.daily_peak_hours * 3600
    )
    monthly_requests = daily_requests * 30

    # Duration and memory
    duration_seconds = traffic.average_response_time_ms / 1000
    memory_gb = memory_mb / 1024

    # Cost calculation
    request_cost = monthly_requests * request_price
    compute_cost = monthly_requests * duration_seconds * memory_gb * gb_second_price

    total_cost = request_cost + compute_cost

    return {
        "monthly_cost": total_cost,
        "monthly_requests": monthly_requests,
        "cost_breakdown": {
            "requests": request_cost,
            "compute": compute_cost
        }
    }

# Example usage
if __name__ == "__main__":
    # E-commerce order service traffic pattern
    traffic = TrafficPattern(
        requests_per_second_avg=10,
        requests_per_second_peak=100,
        average_response_time_ms=200,
        daily_peak_hours=8
    )

    fargate_cost = calculate_fargate_cost(traffic)
    lambda_cost = calculate_lambda_cost(traffic)

    print("Cost Comparison:")
    print(f"Fargate: ${fargate_cost['monthly_cost']:.2f}/month")
    print(f"Lambda:  ${lambda_cost['monthly_cost']:.2f}/month")
    print(f"Savings: ${abs(fargate_cost['monthly_cost'] - lambda_cost['monthly_cost']):.2f}/month")

    Hybrid Deployment Strategy

    The most effective approach often combines both patterns:

    # Service routing based on characteristics
class ServiceDeploymentStrategy:
    def __init__(self):
        self.fargate_services = [
            "order-processing",      # Long-running, stateful
            "inventory-management",  # Consistent traffic
            "user-management",       # Database-heavy
            "payment-processing"     # PCI compliance requirements
        ]

        self.lambda_services = [
            "notification-service",  # Event-driven
            "report-generation",     # Sporadic, compute-intensive
            "image-processing",      # Burst workloads
            "audit-logging",         # Event-driven
            "webhook-handlers"       # Irregular traffic
        ]

    def determine_deployment(self, service_name: str, characteristics: Dict) -> str:
        """Determine optimal deployment pattern based on service characteristics"""

        # Rule-based decision making
        if characteristics.get("requires_persistent_connections"):
            return "fargate"

        if characteristics.get("traffic_pattern") == "irregular":
            return "lambda"

        if characteristics.get("execution_time_minutes", 0) > 10:
            return "fargate"

        if characteristics.get("memory_requirements_gb", 1) > 3:
            return "fargate"

        if characteristics.get("concurrent_connections") > 1000:
            return "fargate"

        # Default to Lambda for event-driven workloads
        return "lambda"

    Monitoring and Observability

    ECS Fargate Monitoring

    # monitoring/fargate_monitoring.py
from aws_cdk import (
    aws_cloudwatch as cloudwatch,
    aws_cloudwatch_actions as cw_actions,
    aws_sns as sns
)

def create_fargate_alarms(service_name: str, cluster_name: str):
    """Create CloudWatch alarms for ECS Fargate service"""

    # SNS topic for alerts
    alert_topic = sns.Topic(f"{service_name}-alerts")

    # CPU Utilization
    cpu_alarm = cloudwatch.Alarm(
        f"{service_name}-high-cpu",
        alarm_description=f"High CPU utilization for {service_name}",
        metric=cloudwatch.Metric(
            namespace="AWS/ECS",
            metric_name="CPUUtilization",
            dimensions_map={
                "ServiceName": service_name,
                "ClusterName": cluster_name
            },
            statistic="Average"
        ),
        threshold=80,
        evaluation_periods=2,
        datapoints_to_alarm=2
    )
    cpu_alarm.add_alarm_action(cw_actions.SnsAction(alert_topic))

    # Memory Utilization
    memory_alarm = cloudwatch.Alarm(
        f"{service_name}-high-memory",
        alarm_description=f"High memory utilization for {service_name}",
        metric=cloudwatch.Metric(
            namespace="AWS/ECS",
            metric_name="MemoryUtilization",
            dimensions_map={
                "ServiceName": service_name,
                "ClusterName": cluster_name
            },
            statistic="Average"
        ),
        threshold=90,
        evaluation_periods=2
    )
    memory_alarm.add_alarm_action(cw_actions.SnsAction(alert_topic))

    # Service health
    running_count_alarm = cloudwatch.Alarm(
        f"{service_name}-low-running-count",
        alarm_description=f"Low running task count for {service_name}",
        metric=cloudwatch.Metric(
            namespace="AWS/ECS",
            metric_name="RunningCount",
            dimensions_map={
                "ServiceName": service_name,
                "ClusterName": cluster_name
            },
            statistic="Average"
        ),
        threshold=1,
        comparison_operator=cloudwatch.ComparisonOperator.LESS_THAN_THRESHOLD,
        evaluation_periods=1
    )
    running_count_alarm.add_alarm_action(cw_actions.SnsAction(alert_topic))

    Lambda Monitoring

    # monitoring/lambda_monitoring.py
def create_lambda_alarms(function_name: str):
    """Create CloudWatch alarms for Lambda function"""

    alert_topic = sns.Topic(f"{function_name}-alerts")

    # Error Rate
    error_rate_alarm = cloudwatch.Alarm(
        f"{function_name}-high-error-rate",
        alarm_description=f"High error rate for {function_name}",
        metric=cloudwatch.Metric(
            namespace="AWS/Lambda",
            metric_name="ErrorRate",
            dimensions_map={"FunctionName": function_name},
            statistic="Average"
        ),
        threshold=5,  # 5% error rate
        evaluation_periods=2
    )
    error_rate_alarm.add_alarm_action(cw_actions.SnsAction(alert_topic))

    # Duration
    duration_alarm = cloudwatch.Alarm(
        f"{function_name}-high-duration",
        alarm_description=f"High duration for {function_name}",
        metric=cloudwatch.Metric(
            namespace="AWS/Lambda",
            metric_name="Duration",
            dimensions_map={"FunctionName": function_name},
            statistic="Average"
        ),
        threshold=25000,  # 25 seconds
        evaluation_periods=3
    )
    duration_alarm.add_alarm_action(cw_actions.SnsAction(alert_topic))

    # Throttles
    throttle_alarm = cloudwatch.Alarm(
        f"{function_name}-throttles",
        alarm_description=f"Function throttling detected for {function_name}",
        metric=cloudwatch.Metric(
            namespace="AWS/Lambda",
            metric_name="Throttles",
            dimensions_map={"FunctionName": function_name},
            statistic="Sum"
        ),
        threshold=1,
        evaluation_periods=1
    )
    throttle_alarm.add_alarm_action(cw_actions.SnsAction(alert_topic))

    Decision Framework and Best Practices

    When to Choose ECS Fargate

    ‚úÖ Choose Fargate when: - Long-running services with consistent traffic - Applications requiring persistent connections - Complex application state or caching needs - Traditional microservices architectures - Need for SSH/exec access for debugging - Compliance requirements for container isolation - Applications with predictable resource requirements

    When to Choose Lambda

    ‚úÖ Choose Lambda when: - Event-driven processing - Irregular or unpredictable traffic patterns - Short-running tasks (< 15 minutes) - Cost optimization is critical - Automatic scaling is essential - Stateless operations - Integration with AWS event sources

    Migration Strategy

    # migration/service_analyzer.py
class ServiceMigrationAnalyzer:
    def analyze_service(self, service_metrics: Dict) -> str:
        """Analyze service for migration recommendation"""

        score_fargate = 0
        score_lambda = 0

        # Traffic pattern analysis
        if service_metrics.get("traffic_coefficient_variation", 1.0) > 2.0:
            score_lambda += 3  # High variability favors Lambda
        else:
            score_fargate += 2  # Steady traffic favors Fargate

        # Execution time
        avg_execution_time = service_metrics.get("avg_execution_time_ms", 1000)
        if avg_execution_time < 30000:  # < 30 seconds
            score_lambda += 2
        elif avg_execution_time > 300000:  # > 5 minutes
            score_fargate += 3

        # Memory requirements
        memory_usage = service_metrics.get("avg_memory_mb", 512)
        if memory_usage < 1024:  # < 1GB
            score_lambda += 1
        elif memory_usage > 3008:  # > 3GB (Lambda limit)
            score_fargate += 3

        # State requirements
        if service_metrics.get("requires_persistent_state", False):
            score_fargate += 3
        else:
            score_lambda += 1

        # Cost sensitivity
        if service_metrics.get("cost_sensitive", False):
            requests_per_month = service_metrics.get("requests_per_month", 1000000)
            if requests_per_month < 10000000:  # < 10M requests
                score_lambda += 2
            else:
                score_fargate += 2

        return "lambda" if score_lambda > score_fargate else "fargate"

    Conclusion

    The choice between ECS Fargate and Lambda for Python microservices isn't binary‚Äîit's about matching each service's characteristics to the optimal deployment pattern. The clean-py repository demonstrates how Clean Architecture enables this flexibility by decoupling business logic from infrastructure concerns.

    Key takeaways:

    1. Service Characteristics Drive Decisions: Analyze traffic patterns, execution time, state requirements, and cost sensitivity
    2. Hybrid Approaches Work Best: Use Fargate for steady-state services, Lambda for event-driven workloads
    3. Architecture Enables Choice: Clean Architecture makes migration between patterns straightforward
    4. Monitor and Optimize: Continuously evaluate service performance and costs to optimize deployment patterns

    Start with Lambda for new services unless you have specific requirements for Fargate. The pay-per-use model and automatic scaling often provide better initial economics. As services mature and traffic patterns stabilize, evaluate migration to Fargate if it offers operational or cost advantages.

    The clean-py patterns provide production-ready templates for both deployment models. Choose based on your specific requirements, not on technology preferences. Your architecture should serve your business needs, not constrain them.

    FastAPI + Clean Architecture: A Match Made in Heaven

    FastAPI has revolutionized Python web development with its modern approach to API design, automatic documentation, and exceptional performance. But many developers treat it as just another web framework, missing the opportunity to leverage its unique features within a Clean Architecture approach. The combination of FastAPI's dependency injection, type safety, and automatic validation with Clean Architecture's separation of concerns creates a powerful foundation for scalable applications.

    The clean-py repository demonstrates how FastAPI and Clean Architecture complement each other perfectly. This isn't just about using FastAPI as a web server‚Äîit's about leveraging its design philosophy to reinforce architectural boundaries and create truly maintainable systems.

    Why FastAPI and Clean Architecture Work So Well Together

    I've built REST APIs with Flask, Django REST Framework, and FastAPI. While each has its strengths, FastAPI's design philosophy aligns uniquely well with Clean Architecture principles:

    Type Safety: FastAPI's reliance on Python type hints enforces contracts between layers, making dependency inversion explicit and checkable.

    Dependency Injection: FastAPI's dependency system naturally implements the dependency inversion principle, making testing and mocking straightforward.

    Automatic Validation: Pydantic integration handles input validation at the presentation layer, keeping domain logic pure.

    Documentation Generation: OpenAPI documentation stays in sync with implementation, reducing maintenance overhead.

    Performance: ASGI foundation provides the performance needed for production systems without sacrificing development velocity.

    A recent project demonstrated this perfectly. We migrated a Django REST Framework API with 50+ endpoints to FastAPI with Clean Architecture. The result: 40% performance improvement, 60% reduction in test execution time, and dramatically improved code maintainability. The architectural boundaries became self-enforcing through FastAPI's type system.

    Clean Architecture Layers with FastAPI

    Let's examine how FastAPI components map to Clean Architecture layers:

‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
‚îÇ                    Application Layer                        ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  ‚Ä¢ Use case classes  ‚Ä¢ Command/Query handlers              ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  ‚Ä¢ Service interfaces                                      ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  ‚Ä¢ FastAPI dependencies for use case injection             ‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
                                ‚îÇ
‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
‚îÇ                     Domain Layer                            ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  ‚Ä¢ Entities          ‚Ä¢ Value objects                       ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  ‚Ä¢ Domain services   ‚Ä¢ Repository interfaces               ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  ‚Ä¢ Business rules    ‚Ä¢ Domain events                       ‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
                                ‚îÇ
‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
‚îÇ                  Infrastructure Layer                       ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  ‚Ä¢ Repository implementations                               ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  ‚Ä¢ Database models   ‚Ä¢ External service clients            ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  ‚Ä¢ FastAPI dependencies for infrastructure injection       ‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò

    This layering provides natural separation of concerns while leveraging FastAPI's strengths at each layer.

    Presentation Layer Implementation

    Router Organization

    The clean-py repository organizes FastAPI routers by domain aggregate, maintaining clean boundaries:

    # src/presentation/routers/orders.py
from fastapi import APIRouter, Depends, HTTPException, status
from typing import List, Optional

from ..dependencies import get_order_service, get_current_user
from ..models.requests import CreateOrderRequest, UpdateOrderRequest
from ..models.responses import OrderResponse, OrderListResponse
from ...application.use_cases.orders import (
    CreateOrderUseCase,
    GetOrderUseCase,
    ListOrdersUseCase,
    UpdateOrderUseCase
)
from ...domain.entities.user import User

router = APIRouter(prefix="/orders", tags=["orders"])

@router.post("/", response_model=OrderResponse, status_code=status.HTTP_201_CREATED)
async def create_order(
    request: CreateOrderRequest,
    current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user),
    create_order_use_case: CreateOrderUseCase = Depends()
) -> OrderResponse:
    """Create a new order for the authenticated user."""

    try:
        order = await create_order_use_case.execute(
            user_id=current_user.id,
            order_data=request.model_dump(),
            requesting_user=current_user
        )
        return OrderResponse.from_domain(order)

    except OrderCreationError as e:
        raise HTTPException(
            status_code=status.HTTP_400_BAD_REQUEST,
            detail=str(e)
        )
    except InsufficientPermissionError as e:
        raise HTTPException(
            status_code=status.HTTP_403_FORBIDDEN,
            detail=str(e)
        )

@router.get("/{order_id}", response_model=OrderResponse)
async def get_order(
    order_id: str,
    current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user),
    get_order_use_case: GetOrderUseCase = Depends()
) -> OrderResponse:
    """Get a specific order by ID."""

    try:
        order = await get_order_use_case.execute(
            order_id=order_id,
            requesting_user=current_user
        )
        return OrderResponse.from_domain(order)

    except OrderNotFoundError:
        raise HTTPException(
            status_code=status.HTTP_404_NOT_FOUND,
            detail="Order not found"
        )

@router.get("/", response_model=OrderListResponse)
async def list_orders(
    limit: int = 50,
    offset: int = 0,
    status_filter: Optional[str] = None,
    current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user),
    list_orders_use_case: ListOrdersUseCase = Depends()
) -> OrderListResponse:
    """List orders for the authenticated user."""

    orders = await list_orders_use_case.execute(
        user_id=current_user.id,
        limit=limit,
        offset=offset,
        status_filter=status_filter,
        requesting_user=current_user
    )

    return OrderListResponse(
        orders=[OrderResponse.from_domain(order) for order in orders.items],
        total=orders.total,
        limit=limit,
        offset=offset
    )

    Request/Response Models

    Pydantic models define the presentation layer contract, separate from domain entities:

    # src/presentation/models/requests.py
from pydantic import BaseModel, Field, validator
from typing import List, Optional, Dict, Any
from decimal import Decimal
from datetime import datetime

class OrderItemRequest(BaseModel):
    product_id: str = Field(..., description="Product identifier")
    quantity: int = Field(..., ge=1, le=100, description="Item quantity")
    unit_price: Optional[Decimal] = Field(None, description="Override unit price")

    @validator('unit_price')
    def validate_unit_price(cls, v):
        if v is not None and v <= 0:
            raise ValueError('Unit price must be positive')
        return v

class AddressRequest(BaseModel):
    street_address: str = Field(..., max_length=255)
    city: str = Field(..., max_length=100)
    state: str = Field(..., max_length=50)
    postal_code: str = Field(..., max_length=20)
    country: str = Field(..., max_length=50)

class CreateOrderRequest(BaseModel):
    items: List[OrderItemRequest] = Field(..., min_items=1, max_items=50)
    shipping_address: AddressRequest
    billing_address: Optional[AddressRequest] = None
    payment_method_id: str = Field(..., description="Payment method identifier")
    discount_code: Optional[str] = Field(None, max_length=50)
    special_instructions: Optional[str] = Field(None, max_length=500)

    @validator('items')
    def validate_items(cls, items):
        # Business validation at presentation layer
        product_ids = [item.product_id for item in items]
        if len(product_ids) != len(set(product_ids)):
            raise ValueError('Duplicate products not allowed')
        return items

    class Config:
        schema_extra = {
            "example": {
                "items": [
                    {
                        "product_id": "prod_123",
                        "quantity": 2,
                        "unit_price": 29.99
                    }
                ],
                "shipping_address": {
                    "street_address": "123 Main St",
                    "city": "Seattle",
                    "state": "WA", 
                    "postal_code": "98101",
                    "country": "US"
                },
                "payment_method_id": "pm_456",
                "discount_code": "SAVE10"
            }
        }

# src/presentation/models/responses.py
from pydantic import BaseModel, Field
from typing import List, Optional, Dict, Any
from decimal import Decimal
from datetime import datetime
from enum import Enum

from ...domain.entities.order import Order
from ...domain.value_objects.money import Money
from ...domain.value_objects.address import Address

class OrderStatus(str, Enum):
    PENDING = "pending"
    CONFIRMED = "confirmed"
    SHIPPED = "shipped"
    DELIVERED = "delivered"
    CANCELLED = "cancelled"

class OrderItemResponse(BaseModel):
    product_id: str
    product_name: str
    quantity: int
    unit_price: Decimal
    total_price: Decimal

class AddressResponse(BaseModel):
    street_address: str
    city: str
    state: str
    postal_code: str
    country: str

    @classmethod
    def from_domain(cls, address: Address) -> 'AddressResponse':
        return cls(
            street_address=address.street_address,
            city=address.city,
            state=address.state,
            postal_code=address.postal_code,
            country=address.country
        )

class OrderResponse(BaseModel):
    id: str
    status: OrderStatus
    items: List[OrderItemResponse]
    subtotal: Decimal
    tax_amount: Decimal
    shipping_cost: Decimal
    discount_amount: Decimal
    total_amount: Decimal
    currency: str
    shipping_address: AddressResponse
    billing_address: Optional[AddressResponse]
    created_at: datetime
    updated_at: datetime

    @classmethod
    def from_domain(cls, order: Order) -> 'OrderResponse':
        """Convert domain entity to response model"""
        return cls(
            id=str(order.id),
            status=OrderStatus(order.status.value),
            items=[
                OrderItemResponse(
                    product_id=str(item.product_id),
                    product_name=item.product_name,
                    quantity=item.quantity,
                    unit_price=item.unit_price.amount,
                    total_price=item.total_price.amount
                ) for item in order.items
            ],
            subtotal=order.subtotal.amount,
            tax_amount=order.tax_amount.amount,
            shipping_cost=order.shipping_cost.amount,
            discount_amount=order.discount_amount.amount,
            total_amount=order.total_amount.amount,
            currency=order.total_amount.currency,
            shipping_address=AddressResponse.from_domain(order.shipping_address),
            billing_address=AddressResponse.from_domain(order.billing_address) if order.billing_address else None,
            created_at=order.created_at,
            updated_at=order.updated_at
        )

    class Config:
        schema_extra = {
            "example": {
                "id": "ord_abc123",
                "status": "confirmed",
                "items": [
                    {
                        "product_id": "prod_123",
                        "product_name": "Premium Widget",
                        "quantity": 2,
                        "unit_price": 29.99,
                        "total_price": 59.98
                    }
                ],
                "subtotal": 59.98,
                "tax_amount": 4.80,
                "shipping_cost": 9.99,
                "discount_amount": 6.00,
                "total_amount": 68.77,
                "currency": "USD"
            }
        }

    Dependency Injection for Clean Architecture

    FastAPI's dependency system beautifully implements dependency inversion:

    # src/presentation/dependencies.py
from fastapi import Depends, HTTPException, status
from typing import Annotated

# Infrastructure dependencies
def get_database() -> Database:
    """Get database connection"""
    return Database(DATABASE_URL)

def get_redis() -> Redis:
    """Get Redis client"""
    return Redis(REDIS_URL)

def get_event_bus() -> EventBus:
    """Get event bus for domain events"""
    return EventBus()

# Repository dependencies
def get_order_repository(
    db: Database = Depends(get_database)
) -> OrderRepository:
    """Get order repository implementation"""
    return SQLOrderRepository(db)

def get_product_repository(
    db: Database = Depends(get_database)
) -> ProductRepository:
    """Get product repository implementation"""
    return SQLProductRepository(db)

def get_user_repository(
    db: Database = Depends(get_database)
) -> UserRepository:
    """Get user repository implementation"""
    return SQLUserRepository(db)

# Service dependencies
def get_payment_service() -> PaymentService:
    """Get payment service implementation"""
    return StripePaymentService(api_key=STRIPE_API_KEY)

def get_inventory_service() -> InventoryService:
    """Get inventory service implementation"""
    return InventoryService()

def get_notification_service() -> NotificationService:
    """Get notification service implementation"""
    return EmailNotificationService()

# Use case dependencies
def get_create_order_use_case(
    order_repo: OrderRepository = Depends(get_order_repository),
    product_repo: ProductRepository = Depends(get_product_repository),
    payment_service: PaymentService = Depends(get_payment_service),
    inventory_service: InventoryService = Depends(get_inventory_service),
    event_bus: EventBus = Depends(get_event_bus)
) -> CreateOrderUseCase:
    """Get create order use case with all dependencies"""
    return CreateOrderUseCase(
        order_repository=order_repo,
        product_repository=product_repo,
        payment_service=payment_service,
        inventory_service=inventory_service,
        event_bus=event_bus
    )

def get_order_service(
    order_repo: OrderRepository = Depends(get_order_repository),
    event_bus: EventBus = Depends(get_event_bus)
) -> OrderService:
    """Get order service with dependencies"""
    return OrderService(
        order_repository=order_repo,
        event_bus=event_bus
    )

# Authentication dependencies
async def get_current_user(
    token: str = Depends(oauth2_scheme),
    user_repo: UserRepository = Depends(get_user_repository)
) -> User:
    """Get currently authenticated user"""
    try:
        payload = jwt.decode(token, SECRET_KEY, algorithms=[ALGORITHM])
        user_id = payload.get("sub")
        if user_id is None:
            raise HTTPException(
                status_code=status.HTTP_401_UNAUTHORIZED,
                detail="Invalid authentication credentials"
            )
    except JWTError:
        raise HTTPException(
            status_code=status.HTTP_401_UNAUTHORIZED,
            detail="Invalid authentication credentials"
        )

    user = await user_repo.get_by_id(user_id)
    if user is None:
        raise HTTPException(
            status_code=status.HTTP_401_UNAUTHORIZED,
            detail="User not found"
        )
    return user

# Type aliases for cleaner code
CurrentUser = Annotated[User, Depends(get_current_user)]
CreateOrderUseCaseDep = Annotated[CreateOrderUseCase, Depends(get_create_order_use_case)]

    Application Layer Integration

    The application layer contains use cases that orchestrate business operations:

    # src/application/use_cases/orders/create_order.py
from typing import Dict, Any
from dataclasses import dataclass

from ...domain.entities.user import User
from ...domain.entities.order import Order
from ...domain.repositories.order_repository import OrderRepository
from ...domain.repositories.product_repository import ProductRepository
from ...domain.services.payment_service import PaymentService
from ...domain.services.inventory_service import InventoryService
from ...infrastructure.events.event_bus import EventBus
from ...domain.events.order_events import OrderCreatedEvent

@dataclass
class CreateOrderCommand:
    user_id: str
    items: list[Dict[str, Any]]
    shipping_address: Dict[str, str]
    billing_address: Dict[str, str]
    payment_method_id: str
    discount_code: str | None = None

class CreateOrderUseCase:
    def __init__(
        self,
        order_repository: OrderRepository,
        product_repository: ProductRepository,
        payment_service: PaymentService,
        inventory_service: InventoryService,
        event_bus: EventBus
    ):
        self.order_repository = order_repository
        self.product_repository = product_repository
        self.payment_service = payment_service
        self.inventory_service = inventory_service
        self.event_bus = event_bus

    async def execute(
        self,
        user_id: str,
        order_data: Dict[str, Any],
        requesting_user: User
    ) -> Order:
        """Execute order creation use case"""

        # Authorization check
        if requesting_user.id != user_id and not requesting_user.is_admin:
            raise InsufficientPermissionError("Cannot create order for another user")

        # Validate products exist and have sufficient inventory
        product_ids = [item['product_id'] for item in order_data['items']]
        products = await self.product_repository.get_by_ids(product_ids)

        if len(products) != len(product_ids):
            missing_ids = set(product_ids) - {str(p.id) for p in products}
            raise ProductNotFoundError(f"Products not found: {missing_ids}")

        # Check inventory
        for item_data in order_data['items']:
            product = next(p for p in products if str(p.id) == item_data['product_id'])
            available = await self.inventory_service.check_availability(
                product.id, 
                item_data['quantity']
            )
            if not available:
                raise InsufficientInventoryError(f"Insufficient inventory for {product.name}")

        # Create order domain entity
        order = Order.create(
            user_id=user_id,
            items_data=order_data['items'],
            products=products,
            shipping_address=order_data['shipping_address'],
            billing_address=order_data.get('billing_address'),
            payment_method_id=order_data['payment_method_id'],
            discount_code=order_data.get('discount_code')
        )

        # Reserve inventory
        for item in order.items:
            await self.inventory_service.reserve_inventory(
                item.product_id,
                item.quantity,
                order.id
            )

        # Process payment
        payment_result = await self.payment_service.process_payment(
            amount=order.total_amount,
            payment_method_id=order_data['payment_method_id'],
            order_id=str(order.id)
        )

        if not payment_result.success:
            # Release reserved inventory
            await self._release_inventory(order)
            raise PaymentProcessingError(payment_result.error_message)

        # Save order
        saved_order = await self.order_repository.save(order)

        # Publish domain event
        await self.event_bus.publish(
            OrderCreatedEvent(
                order_id=str(saved_order.id),
                user_id=saved_order.user_id,
                total_amount=saved_order.total_amount.amount,
                currency=saved_order.total_amount.currency
            )
        )

        return saved_order

    async def _release_inventory(self, order: Order):
        """Release reserved inventory in case of failure"""
        for item in order.items:
            try:
                await self.inventory_service.release_reservation(
                    item.product_id,
                    item.quantity,
                    order.id
                )
            except Exception:
                # Log but don't fail the operation
                pass

    Middleware and Error Handling

    FastAPI middleware integrates cleanly with Clean Architecture concerns:

    # src/presentation/middleware/logging_middleware.py
from fastapi import Request, Response
from starlette.middleware.base import BaseHTTPMiddleware
import time
import uuid

from ...infrastructure.logging import get_logger

logger = get_logger(__name__)

class RequestLoggingMiddleware(BaseHTTPMiddleware):
    async def dispatch(self, request: Request, call_next):
        # Generate correlation ID
        correlation_id = str(uuid.uuid4())
        request.state.correlation_id = correlation_id

        # Log request
        start_time = time.perf_counter()
        logger.info(
            "Request started",
            extra={
                "correlation_id": correlation_id,
                "method": request.method,
                "url": str(request.url),
                "client_ip": request.client.host,
                "user_agent": request.headers.get("user-agent"),
                "content_length": request.headers.get("content-length")
            }
        )

        # Process request
        try:
            response = await call_next(request)
            duration = (time.perf_counter() - start_time) * 1000

            # Log response
            logger.info(
                "Request completed",
                extra={
                    "correlation_id": correlation_id,
                    "status_code": response.status_code,
                    "duration_ms": round(duration, 2),
                    "response_size": response.headers.get("content-length")
                }
            )

            # Add correlation ID to response headers
            response.headers["X-Correlation-ID"] = correlation_id
            return response

        except Exception as e:
            duration = (time.perf_counter() - start_time) * 1000
            logger.error(
                "Request failed",
                extra={
                    "correlation_id": correlation_id,
                    "error": str(e),
                    "error_type": type(e).__name__,
                    "duration_ms": round(duration, 2)
                },
                exc_info=True
            )
            raise

# src/presentation/middleware/exception_handlers.py
from fastapi import Request, HTTPException
from fastapi.responses import JSONResponse
import traceback

from ...domain.exceptions import (
    DomainException,
    OrderNotFoundError,
    InsufficientInventoryError,
    PaymentProcessingError
)
from ...infrastructure.logging import get_logger

logger = get_logger(__name__)

async def domain_exception_handler(request: Request, exc: DomainException):
    """Handle domain-specific exceptions"""
    correlation_id = getattr(request.state, 'correlation_id', 'unknown')

    logger.warning(
        "Domain exception occurred",
        extra={
            "correlation_id": correlation_id,
            "exception_type": type(exc).__name__,
            "exception_message": str(exc),
            "endpoint": str(request.url),
            "method": request.method
        }
    )

    # Map domain exceptions to HTTP status codes
    status_code_mapping = {
        OrderNotFoundError: 404,
        InsufficientInventoryError: 409,
        PaymentProcessingError: 402,
    }

    status_code = status_code_mapping.get(type(exc), 400)

    return JSONResponse(
        status_code=status_code,
        content={
            "error": {
                "type": type(exc).__name__,
                "message": str(exc),
                "correlation_id": correlation_id
            }
        }
    )

async def validation_exception_handler(request: Request, exc: ValidationError):
    """Handle validation errors from Pydantic"""
    correlation_id = getattr(request.state, 'correlation_id', 'unknown')

    logger.info(
        "Validation error occurred",
        extra={
            "correlation_id": correlation_id,
            "errors": exc.errors(),
            "endpoint": str(request.url)
        }
    )

    return JSONResponse(
        status_code=422,
        content={
            "error": {
                "type": "ValidationError",
                "message": "Request validation failed",
                "details": exc.errors(),
                "correlation_id": correlation_id
            }
        }
    )

async def http_exception_handler(request: Request, exc: HTTPException):
    """Handle FastAPI HTTP exceptions"""
    correlation_id = getattr(request.state, 'correlation_id', 'unknown')

    return JSONResponse(
        status_code=exc.status_code,
        content={
            "error": {
                "type": "HTTPException",
                "message": exc.detail,
                "correlation_id": correlation_id
            }
        }
    )

async def internal_server_error_handler(request: Request, exc: Exception):
    """Handle unexpected server errors"""
    correlation_id = getattr(request.state, 'correlation_id', 'unknown')

    logger.error(
        "Unexpected server error",
        extra={
            "correlation_id": correlation_id,
            "exception_type": type(exc).__name__,
            "exception_message": str(exc),
            "endpoint": str(request.url),
            "method": request.method,
            "traceback": traceback.format_exc()
        }
    )

    return JSONResponse(
        status_code=500,
        content={
            "error": {
                "type": "InternalServerError",
                "message": "An unexpected error occurred",
                "correlation_id": correlation_id
            }
        }
    )

    Application Factory Pattern

    The application factory pattern provides clean initialization:

    # src/presentation/main.py
from fastapi import FastAPI, Request
from fastapi.middleware.cors import CORSMiddleware
from fastapi.responses import JSONResponse
from contextlib import asynccontextmanager

from .routers import orders, products, users, auth
from .middleware.logging_middleware import RequestLoggingMiddleware
from .middleware.exception_handlers import (
    domain_exception_handler,
    validation_exception_handler,
    http_exception_handler,
    internal_server_error_handler
)
from ..domain.exceptions import DomainException
from ..infrastructure.logging import configure_logging
from ..infrastructure.database import initialize_database

@asynccontextmanager
async def lifespan(app: FastAPI):
    """Application lifespan manager"""
    # Startup
    configure_logging()
    await initialize_database()

    yield

    # Shutdown
    await cleanup_resources()

def create_application() -> FastAPI:
    """Application factory function"""

    app = FastAPI(
        title="Clean Architecture E-commerce API",
        description="Production-ready e-commerce API built with Clean Architecture principles",
        version="1.0.0",
        docs_url="/docs",
        redoc_url="/redoc",
        lifespan=lifespan
    )

    # Add CORS middleware
    app.add_middleware(
        CORSMiddleware,
        allow_origins=["https://yourapp.com", "https://admin.yourapp.com"],
        allow_credentials=True,
        allow_methods=["GET", "POST", "PUT", "DELETE"],
        allow_headers=["*"],
    )

    # Add custom middleware
    app.add_middleware(RequestLoggingMiddleware)

    # Register exception handlers
    app.add_exception_handler(DomainException, domain_exception_handler)
    app.add_exception_handler(ValidationError, validation_exception_handler)
    app.add_exception_handler(HTTPException, http_exception_handler)
    app.add_exception_handler(Exception, internal_server_error_handler)

    # Include routers
    app.include_router(auth.router, prefix="/api/v1")
    app.include_router(orders.router, prefix="/api/v1")
    app.include_router(products.router, prefix="/api/v1")
    app.include_router(users.router, prefix="/api/v1")

    # Health check endpoint
    @app.get("/health")
    async def health_check():
        return {"status": "healthy", "version": "1.0.0"}

    return app

# Create application instance
app = create_application()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import uvicorn
    uvicorn.run(app, host="0.0.0.0", port=8000)

        products = await create_test_products()

        async with AsyncClient(app=app, base_url="http://test") as client:

                "email": user.email,
                "password": "testpassword"
            })
            assert login_response.status_code == 200
            token = login_response.json()["access_token"]

            headers = {"Authorization": f"Bearer {token}"}

            # Create order
            order_data = {

                    {"product_id": str(products[1].id), "quantity": 1}

                headers=headers

            assert create_response.status_code == 201

            assert order["status"] == "pending"
            assert len(order["items"]) == 2

            # Get order

                headers=headers
            )

        health_status["status"] = "unhealthy"

    Conclusion

    FastAPI and Clean Architecture form a powerful combination that leverages the strengths of both approaches. FastAPI's type safety, dependency injection, and automatic validation reinforce Clean Architecture's separation of concerns and dependency inversion principles.

    The key benefits of this combination:

    1. Type Safety: Python type hints provide compile-time verification of architectural boundaries
    2. Dependency Injection: Natural implementation of dependency inversion principle
    3. Automatic Validation: Pydantic handles presentation layer validation, keeping domain logic pure
    4. Performance: ASGI foundation provides production-ready performance
    5. Documentation: OpenAPI generation stays synchronized with implementation
    6. Testing: Dependency injection enables comprehensive testing at all levels

    The clean-py repository demonstrates these patterns in production-ready code. The result is a system that's both architecturally sound and performant, with clear separation of concerns and comprehensive testing capabilities.

    References

    • Clean-Py Repository - FastAPI with Clean Architecture
    • FastAPI Documentation - Official FastAPI guide
    • Pydantic Documentation - Data validation library
    • Dependency Injection in FastAPI - Official dependency guide

    Start with Clean Architecture principles, leverage FastAPI's unique features to reinforce those boundaries, and build systems that scale both in performance and maintainability. The combination of these approaches creates applications that are truly built to last.

    JWT Authentication in AWS: From Development to Production

    Authentication is the foundation of application security, but implementing JWT tokens correctly in AWS environments presents unique challenges. You need to handle token lifecycle, key rotation, validation performance, and AWS service integration while maintaining security best practices across development, staging, and production environments.

    The clean-py repository demonstrates a production-ready JWT authentication system designed specifically for AWS deployments. This isn't just about generating tokens‚Äîit's about building a comprehensive authentication infrastructure that scales from local development to enterprise production environments.

    The JWT Authentication Journey

    I've seen too many applications implement JWT authentication as an afterthought. They generate tokens with HS256 and a hardcoded secret, validate them with a simple middleware, and assume they're secure. Then production hits:

    • Tokens can't be revoked when users are compromised
    • Key rotation brings down the entire system
    • Performance degrades under load due to expensive validation
    • Integration with AWS services becomes a nightmare
    • Compliance audits reveal security gaps

    A recent consulting client had exactly this problem. Their JWT implementation worked fine with 100 users, but when they scaled to 10,000 users, token validation became a bottleneck. Every request required expensive cryptographic operations, and they had no way to invalidate compromised tokens without changing the global secret key.

    The solution required rebuilding their entire authentication system with production-grade patterns.

    JWT Architecture for AWS

    A robust JWT system in AWS requires several components working together:
